novel_text:
The thing about columns and rows is they’ll accept anything as long as you feed them with a certain obedience. Numbers don’t ask about the drift between your shoulder blades when you wake at three. They let you bring the coffee to your lips (or pretend to) and sit in your chair and tell yourself that you are good at this, that you, Deirdre Keene, are reliable. Spreadsheets do not wonder what you meant to say last week and couldn’t. They do not ask why, sometimes, you forget the taste of sugar.

On Monday mornings in Little Rock the air along Main Street sticks. There’s the little bakery where the baker, a woman named Freda who always wore bright scarves no matter the humidity, rolled out dough behind the window. The men under the flyovers had their guitars and greasy caps and this way of watching traffic like the river was lodged inside the windshield glass. Our office had a blinking sign with KEEFE & BOONE, CPAs stuttering through the heat like a cheap promise. I’d arrive before anyone else, because the office felt cleaner with the lights off, because there are forms of silence you can only catch before eight a.m. I liked to slide into my chair, set my bag down like I was setting down a pet rabbit, lift my hands above the keyboard. That first settling, as if I might breathe myself into the grid.

“You’re early again,” Tasha would say when she came in at eight–thirteen, a stack of mail and her purse knocked against her hip. Tasha is the kind who laughs with her front teeth, and if you tell her a secret she will carry it around like a warm roll in a napkin. Put it on a plate later and ask if you want butter.

“I like the quiet,” I said on that particular Monday. “Helps me remember what I meant to do.”

“What you meant to do was send the Hudson inventory sheet, your noon meeting is Mr. Ellison—oh wait, no, not Ellison. Something else. You know what? I’ll print your schedule. You hungry?”

She said hungry with her mouth buttery. I said I already had a piece of toast, which wasn’t exactly true. I had lifted the toast to my mouth and held it there until I could smell it. I thought I could smell it. Burnt edges, salt of the butter. When I finally set it down there was no bite mark. I didn’t feel like thinking about that part.

Mr. Boone shuffled in a little after nine, straight from his car, tie still folded on the passenger seat, hair laid flat like he’d ironed it with a book. He peeked into my office. “Deirdre. We’ve got—did Tasha tell you? The school board wants an extension. The young woman with the neon shoes called and said they’ve got an auditor coming Monday next, so not to expect—"

“I’ll draft the extension,” I said, fingers already reaching for the letterhead. “Do we have their updated totals on revenue from events?”

“Ask my son, if he ever remembers to show up,” Mr. Boone said. His son never remembered to show up. Sometimes I wondered if the son was a myth. “And Deirdre,” he added, voice softer, "how was yesterday?"

He always asked that. He asked it because my father and his wife, Vivian, invited everyone in the building to the barbeque yesterday, to make a thing of my father’s one-year sobriety chip. I brought coleslaw in a green bowl and smiled and smiled, the kind of smile you put on the counter and slice into pieces. I tried not to look at the backyard and the way the shadows seemed thicker than shade.

“It was fine,” I said. “The ribs were a hit.”

“Good. Good. Tell your dad he tells the best jokes and that none of us believe half his stories, but that’s half his charm.”

“I think the charm is the other half.” It was a joke from the night before and he laughed like he recognized the echo.

He left. Tasha printed my schedule and held it in her hands like she would give me the keys to a car, her nails a fresh raspberry color. “You’ve got an eleven with Teague Caldwell about the signage business, a Zoom at one, then you were going to go over to your dad’s for a minute, if I remember, because—”

“Because I said I would fix the lawnmower,” I finished. “I lied. I can't fix the lawnmower.”

“Use your ‘I have sensitive wrists’ excuse.”

“I don’t have that excuse.”

“You could. It fits you. Dainty wrists, strong opinions.”

I didn’t correct her. I took the schedule and pretended to look it over. On the corner she’d drawn a little sailboat. She does that when she’s thinking about leaving town, even if only in a picture. The boat had a crooked mast. The word GO was scribbled under it.

There isn’t an ocean anywhere near Little Rock, not really, no matter how much the Arkansas River pretends. But I grew up with postcards of coastlines because my mother sent them from California when she remembered, which was every four months or eight or twenty. My father would tape them to the fridge. Your mother thinks of you, he would say, as if thinking were a thick coat you could wrap around me. The postcards had pelicans and fog and lines of tiny houses on cliffs like petits fours. The edges curled and caught pizza grease and the smell of winter potatoes. I touched the glossy sand and thought my fingers might taste like salt.

I didn’t meet Mara until we were both twenty-two. She arrived in our house as if the house had been waiting for her, like her footsteps always belonged there. My father called me from his office one afternoon. He said, “I have something surprising but good, I think good. I want you to meet someone.”

“Like a dog?"

He laughed, caught, then quiet, like he wanted to be brave. “Like a person.”

It was a restaurant with black napkins and the kind of light that wanted you to be lonely but not alone. He had Vivian beside him, small, fingers wrapped in rings like vines. Vivian’s daughter sat across from them, looking like she had been put in that chair by a pair of careful hands. Mara Ellison. That is where the name belonged, in a sentence like that, as if the book had finally turned the page to reveal the name italicized. She had a cardigan with two missing buttons and a small scar on her chin that made her face somehow true.

Mara looked at me, then at the bread plate, then back at me, as if calibrating. “My mother talks very fast,” she said by way of hello, and I laughed, and the two of us fell into talking like people who have already survived something together. We had not. But that energy was in the room, like an aftertaste.

“I’m an x-ray tech,” she said, tearing her bread in a way that made crumbs like snow. “I like looking at the ghost-map of people.”

My father coughed. “You like being able to see inside people," he corrected, like she had made a faux pas. She shrugged.

“No, I said what I meant,” Mara said, but then smiled at him like she was sorry for being herself. “I grew up in Florida,” she added. “I’m still getting used to not smelling salt in the morning. That sounds pretentious. Sorry.”

“It does, but I forgive you,” I said. There was the river. There were the postcards. My childhood lived between water and the idea of water. “We have the river,” I told her. “When it’s hot, and the air heavy, if you close your eyes on the Junction Bridge you can hear the ocean pretending.”

“That’s not how pretending works,” she said softly.

“Maybe it is.”

She stared at me until it felt like the stare went through and through, like those films she developed. Later, when Vivian and my father had their heads close, telling each other a story without words, Mara and I leaned on the railing outside the restaurant. A delivery truck breathed out a moan down by the alley and teenagers clumped past like birds. The sky had gone that gummy mauve it gets in August, the air thought it was syrup.

“I’m glad we’re the same age,” she said.

“Me too,” I said. I meant: me too, that makes this all less strange. I meant: we could have been anything. I didn’t mean the thing I would mean later.

We became family quickly, which is to say we tripped into each other's patterns and then pretended to have meant to do it. On Sundays, Vivian made pancakes and put berries into little white bowls as if berries deserve to be handled like jewels. My father pretended he knew anything about cars and so did I. Mara corrected us and actually fixed the thing we were staring at. She had thick hair that smelled like applesauce or at least my memory told me it did. We went to the dog park even though we did not have a dog, to point at the dogs and say that one, not that one, that one. We took my father to a meeting in a church basement where a man named Beau with bright eyes hugged him and said “Keep coming back” like a spell. We came back, all of us, and then back again.

It is a way of saying that we were a family before my father and Vivian got the paper. It is a way of saying the paper changed the vocabulary and not the thing. While we signed documents at a courthouse that had too much echo, while Vivian cried and my father wiped at her nose with a cocktail napkin, Mara took a photo of the four of us and put it online with the caption new math. The likes stacked up, little blue thumbs in a parade. I sat on the steps and looked at it and felt weirdly tall and then small as a bird. Sometimes I felt like my palms were empty, even when they held my purse and the rubber stamp and my keys.

At work, the green numbers slid straight and I got raises that didn't feel like anything. At home, I watched Mara carry a plant from room to room looking for the light like she was practicing something. When she got a job at the hospital three exits down, she brought her scrubs home and threw them in the corner and took her shoes off and tried to shake off all the bones she had looked at during the day. “Ankle,” she would say, rotating her hand like a compass. “Radius. A snapped rib that looked like bent chalk. The art of what isn't heart failure. A boy who keeps tripping over his cat and swears it’s the cat’s fault.”

“You’re a collector,” I teased.

“I’m trying not to bring them home,” she said, and then leaned her head on my shoulder and I forgot for a moment how to breathe. She lifted it quick, as if she noticed something had shifted and was trying to correct for it, like holding a tray someone bumped.

We were careful. That is not the same thing as being blind. We each dated, badly, like we were running errands other people wanted us to run. I sat across from a man who sold copy machines and listened to his story about going to Cabo with his college buddies. I went home and told Mara and she put her fist under her chin and listened with wide eyes and said “No,” when he texted later, as if she knew the inside of me like one of her films. She went to the riverfront with a woman who sold handmade jewelry and came back with green ears. “I think they were painted,” she said. “It makes me mad to think about lead.”

“Everything turns out to be painted,” I said, because sometimes I can’t help myself and say a line that wants to sit like a stone in the room.

“Maybe you mean plated?” she asked, smiling.

“Maybe I do.”

I wasn’t sure what I meant. Peeled grapes in a dish. A word said enough without meaning gets soft, gets mushy, you can swallow it like a pill.

If this were a different story, one with an easy moral, I could say that the first time I realized I was in love was the day Mara cut her hair. She stood in the bathroom and looked at herself the way people look at maps when the road is closed. She took the scissors and made the first hard snip, and the sound went through me like the pluck of a string. Hair fell on her shoulders and clung to her shirt, an animal that didn't want to be evicted. She turned to me with a small, almost panicked laugh. “Oh, this was a bad idea.”

“It’s perfect,” I said, too fast, and then saw that it actually was. She was herself without the extra. Something clean and sharp and tender.

“If I look like a fourteen-year-old boy, you have to tell me,” she said.

“You don’t,” I said. “You look like—” I stopped because anything I would say might be too thoroughly true and that would change the room. “You look like yourself,” I said lamely, and she rolled her eyes and threw her hair into the trash in a soft, alive pile.

There were other days that could be candidates. The day at the flea market when she held up a cracked blue plate and made a grand speech about how the crack would let the light in. The night she stood at the sink and cried at the end of a podcast, and I stood with her, two women staring into a basin of water as if trying to read it. The afternoon we both came down with norovirus and took turns being brave and it turned out she was braver and it turned out I loved her for being braver and for letting me pretend. Love doesn’t arrive like a marauder. It keeps house and rearranges the chairs.

Of course, there were signs I should have been seeing, too, and I saw them but decided they were not signs. When our old cat—hers from Florida and ours from the minute her mother left her in our foyer with a carrier and a box of her belongings—decided to ignore me and then curl himself around the leg of the couch when I sat down, as if I were air. When my breath fogged the bathroom mirror less than her breath did, even though I leaned in and huffed. When Vivian asked me, in front of the fridge, whether I remembered the day I broke my wrist at the skating rink, and I said yes and told her about the spinning, the music, the smell of nachos, and then noticed how her face rearranged and how she said, gently, “Honey, that was me. I told you that story last month.”

I laughed too loud. “I’m stealing your material,” I said. “I knew I heard it somewhere.”

The night after my father fell off the wagon—three days and then it just as suddenly was over; Beau's hug seemed to work like a hand on a thermostat—we sat in the backyard in the dark, Mara and me, feet bare, grass like a damp towel. It had rained and everything smelled like the underside of the world. She said, “I keep dreaming of a shore. Like wooden steps and algae. I can hear someone calling down the beach. It’s not Florida. It’s—"

“Cold,” I said without meaning to. “The wind comes in with teeth. The foam is brown. There’s a pier with a shuttering board on the end. You always want to look over but you know you won’t like what’s there.”

She stilled. “How did you know that?”

“I don't know," I said, trying to laugh it off. "Maybe I just know beaches. Maybe Tasha drew me a boat.”

“It’s not funny,” she said. She turned her head. Even in the dark, I felt the outline of her attention like a weight. “If you had been with me, you would know this isn’t sunshine beach. It’s—"

“Sharp,” I said. “I know. Sorry. I didn’t mean to mock.”

She exhaled. “You don’t. Not ever,” she said, which turned out not to be true, if you count what came later as a kind of mockery, the universe’s mean joke, the big bad trick. But in that moment we sat with our knees touching. She was warm, and I tried to feel the warmth like a proof of my own temperature.

You can survive for a long time by telling yourself you are simply dramatic. You can explain the flicker in the corner of your eye as screen fatigue and the way the hallway light buzzes when you walk under it as old wiring. You can say that the cashier not looking up when you hand her a bill is a symptom of modern life and not what it is: sometimes your hands don’t feel like they exist even to you. For a long time I lived like this, between explanations, keeping a list in my head like grocery items. You need bread. You need milk. You need to believe in gravity.

Mara suggested a trip. “A little one,” she said. “We have four days in October when both of us can go.”

She printed a map on the office printer when she stopped by to bring me a sandwich and stood in my doorway and held it up. “New Orleans?” she offered, and then shrugged like she was trying on a dress. “Or Gulf Shores. I know, I know, touristy. Or we could be fancy and go up the coast. We could just go to Lake Ouachita and pretend it’s an ocean.”

“Let’s go to the ocean,” I said too quick. My mouth outran me.

“You’re not a planner,” she teased. “I like this side of you.”

“I look good on the coast,” I said, doing my voice the way my mother had done, that self-mockery kept barely at the edge of fun. The truth is: I wanted something to end. Or to start. My life measured itself between ledgers, between other people’s true stories. The ocean seemed like an honest thing. It doesn’t pretend to hold.

We set the date. Vivian put three kinds of snacks in a basket and called it “for the road” like we were leaving for the army. My father held my face in his hands and kissed my forehead and whispered “Don’t be too…you,” and then laughed and said, “Kidding. Be yourself. Always be yourself. Take care of my girls.” It was a joke, but he meant it, and I watched how his expression moved like water when he looked from me to Mara and back, proud and afraid in the way of men who have learned how much they can lose.

We did all the regular road trip things. We bought Coca-Colas in glass bottles because it mattered to Mara that the bottles were glass. We sang to a playlist she had made that would probably embarrass a certain strain of person—Abba next to a Portuguese fado she found online, old country next to something that sounded like it had been recorded in a closet in Queens. She told me about a patient who had, in the most patient way, explained to her the difference between cartilage and a donut. I told her about the time Mr. Boone had called me Deborah for six months and how I never corrected him because I wanted to see when the lie would run out of gas.

At a rest stop outside of Biloxi, Mara took a picture of the sky like a tourist and then of me like a spy. “Don’t,” I said, laughing and holding my hand up and then lowering it because I wanted the picture to exist and also didn’t. She showed me the photo. My mouth was half-open, like I had been about to catch a word, and my eyes were too big. The color was off, somehow, like the pictures of dead people in old houses. She clicked and clicked. In one of them, my arm looked faint, as if the sun had eaten it. “The exposure’s weird,” she said. “My phone’s acting up.”

“It always acts up when you drive through low country,” I told her. I would have told her anything. If she had said the moon was just a lamp held by a patient god, I would have asked if we needed to dust it.

We arrived at the coast just before sunset. It was that hour that makes storybooks feel brave, when the water isn’t blue so much as a scraped metal color, scuffed and shining. The hotel was two blocks from the beach and the woman at the desk had a name tag that said SANDI with an i. She gave us two paper keys and a list of restaurants and a look like she’d seen all kinds of couples and didn’t commit any of them to paper. We threw our bags on the top of the bedspread like we had been taught not to and ran down to the shore.

It is foolish to say the sand looked like sugar, but it did, and my feet remembered something my brain did not. The ocean had its whole complicated body out in front of us, doing its math. Mara stood with her arms crossed against the wind and let out a laugh like she couldn’t help it. “This is so stupidly good,” she said. A little boy ran past with a kite that couldn’t decide what it wanted to do. An old woman held her shoes in her hand like a bouquet. A couple took turns taking pictures of each other with the horizon like a dare.

“I want to swim,” I said.

“In your jeans? The water’s cold.”

“It’s fine,” I said, which is something I often say when it isn’t. I rolled my pants up and went in to my calves and then to my knees, and something in me went still. The water wasn’t cold enough to be a shocking cold. It was the kind of cold that made your bones ring. I walked out until my jeans were heavy and I thought of all the times, as a kid, I put my feet in the tub and pretended it was a shoreline and let my father teasingly complain about the water on the floor. I thought: you are the kind of woman who comes to the shore and doesn’t know how to behave.

Mara held back because her mother’s voice lived in her somewhere and said you catch a chill fast. She stood with her shoes looped on her fingers like a second pair of lungs and watched me. “Deirdre,” she said, like a warning, and also like a poem. The light made it hard to see her face. For a blink, the horizon bent. This happens sometimes when your eyes decide they will not be bossed.

I didn’t go far, but when the wave reached past my knees and pulled, for an instant it was like something under the surface had my ankles between two fingers. Stronger than I’d expected. I sucked my breath and staggered and grabbed whatever was nearest. My hand went to air. There was an emptiness that had texture. I righted myself and laughed, because we laugh when we are scared and do not want to change the mood of a day. “Okay,” I said to the water. “Okay, boss.”

“Come back,” Mara said. When I waded in fully again, my legs were without their handcuffs. She took my arm, not because I needed it, but to claim me, and the claim spelled itself all the way up to my shoulder.

We ate seafood at a place with paper on the tables and a waitress who wore a silver beluga tail on a chain. The fries were too thin. Mara dipped hers in three sauces, constructing the bite like it mattered. She told me about her mother—about Vivian’s early morning dances in the kitchen, about the times she woke up to find a note and ten dollars and the sense she had to be twice alive to account for all the places her mother went to be alive. I told Mara about the time my mother sent me a postcard and forgot to write my name, how I stared at the blank as if it might tell me something about fate.

“Do you think it was meant,” she asked, “that we would be family?”

“People say everything is meant to make their heartbreaks into lesson plans,” I said, which was unkind. “Maybe it was luck. Maybe it was an accident that we held onto.”

“You think too hard,” she said. She aimed the tip of a fry at me and laughed. That sound was like a rope tossed, not a rope pulled.

We walked back to the hotel, both of us sand-dusted and tired in the best way, missing the details we’d miss on purpose in the morning for the sake of a better story. In the small guest shop, I held up a seashell night light and said, “For Vivian,” and she held up a T-shirt that said SALTY in block letters and flipped it to show the back said BUT SWEET, and we groaned like old people. She bought a little blue fish for the dashboard of her car, a creature with googly eyes, its little suction cup mouth ready.

That night, I slept in the second bed and stared up at the ceiling until I felt my heart would reduce itself to math. The hotel air conditioner swallowed and spit air. The curtain trembled. Mara lay in the other bed, her breath the soft shift of a tide. I thought about getting up and moving into her bed, about making the air a different shape with my body and how it would feel to put my knee against hers and fit into some shared city of sleep we had by now built with our walking and our laughter. I did not move. I lay there as long as I could. Dawn is always a humiliation, a proof of your inability to decide.

In the morning, we ran. Mara runs like an old film star, everything graceful and slightly faster than you’d think. I run like a person running from a bee. We went up the boardwalk and down the firm sand near the water line and then cut back toward a jetty that shoved itself into the body of the sea like a crooked arm. A handful of fishermen, quiet, the kind of quiet that knows something. A man in a white cap nodded and spoke the way men at the ocean do, as if the ocean has made them kind. “Morning.”

“Morning,” we said. My cheeks felt hot. The wind tried to put its hands in my pockets to see if I was telling the truth. We went out to the end of the jetty because people always go to the end. It is what you do with ends. The water here hit the rocks like it wanted to eat them. Mara said, “Careful,” and I said, “I am,” and the rock under my foot told a different story.

I did not fall. That happened later, to her, and the whole world turned on it. But this morning, T minus some days, I slid and my hand went down to catch me, found nothing, found out that touch was not a reliable narrator. I righted myself with a jerk so sharp my neck popped.

“You good?” Mara asked, looking at me with that narrow way she had when she was weighing whether she should call a doctor.

“I’m good,” I said, too bright, and we turned back.

If I made a list of clues, it would read like a bad detective novel. The spoon that fell and no one heard. The way the woman at the front desk looked right over me when we asked for extra towels, and I told myself this is how front desk women are trained and then watched her eyes track across me like across a window. The man on the beach selling puka shells who put his tray in front of Mara and said “Ma’am,” as if the rest of the air was just the thing she was made out of. The photo Mara took of me on the steps of the pier, the one where my face looked double, like paper copied badly. She deleted it undeleted it deleted it again and said, quietly, “I don’t understand what setting is doing that,” as if the setting were inside me and she was trying not to name it.

We left the ocean after two days when we had meant to stay four because of a call from the hospital that a freezer was down and Mara had a kind of duty that glowed in her and I loved that duty because it gave the day a shape. We were good at turning around, the two of us; we had practice. On the way back, traffic coagulated and then broke apart and we passed a billboard that said IF YOU DIED TODAY WHERE WOULD YOU GO in a font that looked like someone’s hard breath. I said a smart thing about evangelical marketing and Mara did not answer. She put her hand on the back of my neck for a second and left it there as if to steady me, and we were both quiet.

Being from Little Rock is like being from any place, which is to say it has a bridge you think is ugly but sometimes looks like an altar in the right light. It has people who always wear shorts and people who always say “bless” and mean it and don’t. It has a place that fries catfish in the back and a place with pizzas so good a part of your mind goes to Ohio for no reason. It has the river and the way the river means you might leave, even if you won’t. We came home to all of this and I let it wrap around me like a routine. Mara went to the hospital and I went back to the office. Tasha asked if we saw dolphins and I lied and said yes, because she wanted me to have seen them. Mr. Boone stood in my door with his hands in his pockets and asked how the water was. “Wet,” I said, and he nodded like I’d offered a concept.

That weekend, our neighborhood had a block party on a street that spilled into ours. The kind with kids on scooters and a folding table greedy with beans and slaws and cans of beer sweating like they were embarrassed to be from a plant. Vivian wore new sandals that had too much strategy on the straps. My father told his good joke about accidentally eating a candle and saying it tasted like rose, and then he told it again to a different cluster. I drifted between the group by the grill and the group on the curb and the group under the pear tree like plankton in a gentle current. Mara was talking to a woman from the next block about knees. Her hands drew circles in the air. She looked up and saw me and smiled in a way that made a line from her to me that anyone could see, a clothesline, a thing with pegs.

“Deirdre,” Vivian said beside me, and I turned because her voice was pitched wrong. “Honey, I…do you want anything? Are you all right? You look a little pale.”

“I’m always pale,” I said. My mouth was dry. There’s always an explanation. She touches my shoulder, it is cool.

“There’s something,” she began, then shook her head. She had that look she gets when she knows a recipe calls for a spice she doesn’t have and she’s trying to make her tongue remember its name. “I forget what I meant to say.”

We sat on the curb as the kids made galaxies with their chalk. Mara joined us. She put her chin on her knees and watched the oldest boy draw a whale. “That’s not how whales look,” she said to him, and he shrugged and said, “It’s how mine do,” and she conceded the point.

“I want to go to the ocean again,” she said, softly, to me. “Soon. Before the cold does whatever it does to people.”

“We just went,” I said, equally soft, because I had a slight stupid fear that if we said it too loudly, someone would hear, and what they would hear is not the word ocean but something else. “Let’s go,” I added, because fear be damned, and her hand slid near mine on the pavement and didn’t touch. She drew her finger in the dust and made a shape that could have been a fish. Or an ear. Or a wish.

Later that night, after the folding tables had returned to garages and the paper lanterns had been persuaded back into their flat selves, after my father had put his coin on the windowsill like a talisman and sent me a text that said simply good night, I lay in bed and listened to the house talk. Houses do, when you let them. The ice maker coughed its little stones. The hallway learned about shadows. I thought of the ocean like you think of someone who has touched your hair and then gone into another room.

When sleep came, finally, it was not the kind where you float. It had mass. I dreamed I was on a pier that had no visible boards. I dreamed I could hear Mara calling—not for me but my name, hard, like a knuckle on a door. The water did a dangerous thing. And then I woke with my throat closed and my hands reaching for a railing that was not there. The light on my phone said four-oh-two. A word sat at the top of my mouth. I swallowed it before it could name me.

Morning, and the light that comes through our kitchen window made our cheap tile look like an expensive idea. Mara had beat me to the coffeepot and was reading the news on her phone with the grimness of a person who wants to know what mess she’s walking into. She pushed a mug toward me across the counter. I wrapped my hands around it. Sometimes the only thing that proves you exist is the shape your hands make around the everyday.

“Do you ever feel like you’ve already done this? I don’t mean just déjà vu,” she said without looking up. “I mean like you’re repeating a phrase until it stops meaning anything. Coffee, coffee, coffee.”

“I always feel like that," I said. "Doesn't everybody?"

“Everyone doesn’t say it like it’s consolation,” she answered, trying to grin, but her eyes wobbled in their set like light on the bottom of a pool. She stared at me then, and it was a look that pulled me as a tide pulls a small boat that has no anchor. She said my name, very gently. “Deirdre. I…”

Her phone rang. The hospital. A voice she obeyed without liking to. She put the mug down in a way that made no sound. She said okay twice and then okay again and then hung up. “Storm coming,” she said. “They want me to come in early in case power goes out and they need to move the portable units. I might need to stay overnight.”

“I’ll drop you,” I said. I already had my keys. I already had my shoes. Sometimes your body does what you think.

She put her palm against my jaw just for a second as if to say yes, we are in the same room. “You can’t,” she said, half laughing. “Your eleven, remember? Teague Caldwell? Signs? The man who says Friendly like he’s saying the opposite?”

“I'll reschedule,” I said. After a pause, I said, “No, I won’t,” because I knew the shape of my day, because I thought there would be time to do all the things later, including the ones we were not naming.

The rain came in sideways. Little Rock does rain like this sometimes, a temper tantrum, and then the sun as if to say, I didn't mean it. By noon, it was a proper storm. Lights flickered. Tasha wrote me in all caps from her desk: IF YOU DIE CAN I HAVE YOUR COOL STAPLER. I wrote back: YES BUT YOU HAVE TO CARRY IT EVRYWHERE TO HONOR ME. She wrote: I WILL STAPLE THE SKY and sent a cat gif. Mr. Boone said we would close early as soon as the land made its decision. I thought about Mara in her basement rooms, the hum of the machines they moved so carefully. I thought about my father sitting on his couch and letting the news tell him what he already knew. I thought about Vivian knitting a complicated thing out of blue.

I went to the window and laid my hand against the glass because sometimes the touch of the outside makes the inside true. My hand did not leave a print. The thought arrived—simple, like a bead.

I turned away quickly, because the difference between a bead and a noose is what you string with it.

At three, the storm took the light for a minute. Someone down the hall said, “There it goes,” like talking to a child that had gotten close to a hot stove, and then it came back. My computer rebooted itself and decided I was not me and refused my password twice and then relented like a mother bargaining with a baby. The quiet that follows an almost-outage is different, as if a bigger quiet had rolled through the one you keep at your desk. I got my bag and my raincoat and told Tasha to go home. She saluted me with a ruler. Mr. Boone had already vanished, which is his gift.

The road from the office to the hospital is only a few turns. It took me twice as long because the streets had become a different set of rules. The water did that thing where it tries to decide whether to swallow or let go. I drove carefully, not because I was patient but because care was all I had left. When I pulled into the section of the garage that Mara had told me to use, a big foam mattress leaned against one wall, a thing that had a job I couldn’t imagine. I ran. The automatic doors opened like a mouth and I stepped in and past the sanitizer a volunteer held like a chalice and down to the basement.

“Ma’am,” the man at the desk said as I passed, “visiting hours are—” and then he looked at me and his mouth smoothed out, the way faces do when they decide they haven't seen you. He turned to his computer screen like it had just asked him a question. I could have laughed. I could have cried. I kept walking.

In the basement, the air smells like wet metal and long plans. I went by the vending machines, the same ones that had broken our hearts at two in the morning that time Vivian’s sister had her gallbladder out and nobody wanted chips. I saw a group of people in blue gowns move a machine that looked like a stalagmite. I did not see Mara. I did not expect to. It is a big building. I turned, the way you do when you are trying not to be lost. A woman in scrubs said, “Can I help you find something?” and I said, “Some one,” and she said, “Oh. Who?” and I said the name of my step-sister.

The woman repeated Mara’s name, once, like it was a test, and then again, like a whisper. “She’s in East,” she said, gesturing with her thumb in a direction that could be any direction. “She lives there on weekends. The wind is worse on that side. Seems to cheer her.”

“Thank you,” I said, because gratitude is a path you can lay down in front of you when there is only fluid and no floor.

Mara was where she had promised the world she would be, steady and moving, making easy light jokes as she helped someone’s mother find the bathroom. She saw me and her face—yes—her face changed, but not the way a person’s face might change if they saw a ghost. It was the change you make for a friend showing up in the rain when you didn’t ask them to. “You,” she said, like a gentle accusation.

“Me,” I said.

She wiped her hands on her scrub pants even though they were clean. “If you’re here to tell me to go home when they let me go, to sleep, I promise I will. If you’re here to say you’ll hold my place in line for bread if everyone panics, I will text you when the line forms. If you’re here to lurk like a bad omen, to look at me with those big eyes, to—”

“I wanted to see you,” I said, cutting her off because her words were pinning me like insects to cork. “I wanted to make sure you’re okay.”

She moved in, a fraction, as if that were a thing her body had learned as a trick. It felt like there were other ocean days behind us already, all of them stacked in a neat pile we would call memory. “I am, so far,” she said.

I reached toward her, for a hand, for a shoulder. I did not touch anything. Either my fingers failed me or the air refused. She flinched anyway, and then frowned, as if she’d been struck by an idea she didn’t like and wanted to hand it back to the universe.

“Go home,” she said, but not unkindly. “Make sure Vivian’s got a candle and your dad’s not using this as an excuse to make Irish coffee. Tell Tasha to take her stapler if she hasn’t already left. Call me when you park. Wait—no—text; they yell when I talk on the floor.”

I wanted to say something else. I wanted to say the word that had sat in my mouth at four-oh-two. I wanted to say I love you in the voice you reserve for the last minute and the first. I put my mouth around the word. The lights blinked again. Someone down the hall made a mess of equipment. Mara looked past me, automatically, as you do, as she had to. It is one of the marks of her goodness that she looks away from her own story when someone calls for help. I let the word go back where it had hidden.

On the way out, a man in the elevator looked at me like I had borrowed his coat and not offered to return it. I said sorry. He pressed his lips together like closure. The storm had moved on; it always moves. The city shone the way it does after rain, as though every surface has been rehearsing for this role.

My phone shook in my hand when I was almost home. Tasha’s name. I pulled over. She had sent a photo of my desk chair with a note: I SPUN IT TWICE FOR YOU. COME BACK TOMORROW. She added four hearts and a sailboat.

I texted back a picture of the road with the wipers mid-stroke and said: the water is a comedian, and she sent back: that joke was bad.

At home, Vivian had candles anyway, three, even though the lights held. My father watched the weather and made commentary as if his opinions could move systems. He said whether he had eaten a candle again and I told him no one believes him, and he looked pleased, like he loved being known so well. We played a game with cards and Vivian cheated without meaning to and I cheated with great intention. I went to sleep and dreamed again of the shore. I heard my name. Once, just once, a voice said: Dierdre. They spelled me wrong. It broke me in a weird fleshy place. In the morning, I found a grain of sand under my tongue, and I laughed because there is only so much you can do with coincidence.

What I am trying to do is tell it whole. How we were before the real beginning. How we walked toward the same bad and good. How I stood at the edge of the river in Little Rock and watched it pull and release and told myself that it was just water, just water, as if I didn’t already know that what is just a thing can also be the whole of it, the main act. How my body had, already, started telling me the punchline before the joke had been set up. How I looked at Mara and saw not only her face but the place beyond it where my own breath made shapes and disappeared. How I insisted on believing that you could go to the sea and not come back different.

Later, when we stood on a different shoreline and the sky took a mouthful of her and I ran out and I couldn’t catch what the world had peeled off the world, later, when I would try to hold a towel or a life preserver or a hand and find myself holding the idea of holding, I would look back on these days and want to smash the small domestic idols of our routine. The mugs, the pens, the night light shaped like a shell. I would think of the spreadsheet on my computer and how the boxes waited with so much patience and how betrayed they would be if they could feel anything. I would think of how the man at the garage had looked through me like I was a window and how the child’s chalk did not dust the side of my hand when I dragged it across the whale. I would think of Vivian’s almost-story. Of my father’s almost-courage. Of my own almost-mouth.

But that comes after. For now, I am not a bad detective with a messy corkboard; I am simply a woman in Arkansas who keeps a neat one-bedroom, who pays the water bill on time, who knows the way to Gulf Shores and back, who has learned the names of her neighbors’ dogs, who knows the weight of her father’s coin in her palm, who writes in a ledger a line each day that says, in its own neat columns, I was here. I was here. I was here. Even if the ink doesn't know me, even if the page is only pretending to listen. Even if, when I turn to look for my reflection, there is nothing but the window, which is a way to say the world, which is a way to say: not yet. Not yet. Not yet.On Wednesday morning the heat returned as if it had left something behind and came back for it, and Main Street got that varnished look it wears when the humidity stands in the doorway with its arms wide. I went early to Freda’s bakery because I thought maybe sugar could teach me its language again if I spoke to it at the source. The window was fogged near her elbows where she was leaning over the dough, and her scarf today was a citrus orange that made her look like a certain kind of bird that knows what to do with wind. When the bell rang and I stepped in, the cool air kissed my arms like a grandmother who had forgiven me for everything in advance. I held the thought that I could be a woman who buys a small paper bag and walks to work with a bun that she intends to eat in three bites and then discovers it takes seven. Freda’s niece manned the register and asked, in that way some young people have that turns every question into a dare, “What can I get for you?” and I said, “What you would give your favorite teacher if you needed her to grade you easy,” and she laughed and handed me a raspberry thing with sugar jewels jeweled so hard they looked like polish.

Back at my desk, when the ribbon of city traffic outside had turned into a sound with a shape I recognized, I took a bite. It was good in the way beauty can be good even if you can’t name its parts, and then there was a hiccup in my head where flavor ought to open. I chewed and knew texture, knew seed and butter and the cold from the case, but there was nothing that would answer to the name sweet. I reached for my coffee to see if it could prune back the blank and sipped and thought of faucet water and then of nothing at all. Tasha came in on her minute with the mail and the purse bang and saw my face do a geometry and said, “Don’t like?” and I told her, because honesty is sometimes a rebellion, “I can’t tell,” and she put her hand on the desk near mine like she was pressing the paper from curling. She has a gift for standing next to trouble in a way that makes it look like company. “Maybe you need salt,” she said, and we laughed because we are citizens of this country where advice lives like air.

Teague Caldwell did come at eleven and filled my doorway with opinions and fabric. He sells signs, which makes him sound like a man who would’ve thrived in another century, holding up painted boards at a fair and shouting the futures they would give you if you let them. He wore a shirt the color of new pennies and showed me a set of mock-ups for a barbecue joint that wanted to look like it had been there forever. He did that thing where he put his finger halfway into the air as if the finger itself could draw a better line. He said Friendly twice as if it were a safety word and then apologized for saying it too much and I forgave him because there are words I use like salt too. He asked for water in a way that made me get up and I led him to the little machine near the credenza and pulled two paper cones and filled them and handed one to him and he took it and then looked at the other and then at me as if there were a third person standing between us who’d gotten the second cup. He drank his water and I drank mine and he wiped his moustache even though it did not need wiping. I returned to my chair and felt it receive me with the relief of a dog who has been left too long and feared it was abandonment, and I smiled at that thought because it made the furniture love me.

After he left, Tasha leaned in and whispered the gossip she had saved as if she were sliding a pastry across to me under the register. “Guess who called me ‘Sasha’ and then wrote ‘Deidra’ on the message,” she said, and I sighed and said, “Does it rhyme with Bone?” and she nodded and rolled her eyes so hard they made a smiley shape in her head. The door to the hall made that breathing sound it makes when the air system decides to remember itself. The sign outside the window buzzed and then quieted and then buzzed again like it was thinking about making a point and then realized the point required more energy than it had stored.

My father texted at two the way he does, like a clock he thinks he has trained. He uses punctuation for sincerity. Meeting at six if you want, sweetheart. I read it twice and felt the rubber-band pull of obligation and also love, which in our house sometimes share a drawer. I told him yes, I would go, and he wrote back a heart and then the word “proud” and then the word “chip” and then said sorry for saying chip too much and I told him there are worse words to say too much and he wrote back “whiskey” and then sent six laughing faces as if he was afraid he had done a wrong. I told Tasha I had to leave a little early to make a church basement look like a safe place, and she drew me a boat on a sticky note and made the mast straight this time.

The church stood on a corner that collects leaves as though it wanted to tuck them in for later. We had been before. We knew the chairs and which ones wobbled and which smell of coffee has the least ambition. Beau was there with his eyes and his smile that might once have been a different man’s weapon and now belonged to everyone. He hugged my father like you hug a cliff after the storm and did that man thing with the backs of hands and the word “buddy,” and then hugged me too, which I accepted, even though sometimes my skin doesn’t know what to do with love when it arrives wearing a body. We sat in chairs that make your back know itself. Vivian came late because she had been making a soup for the neighbor down the street who just birthed a human and was trying to feed everyone in the city to seduce sleep. The meeting began the way they begin, with ritual and then the part where people say their names and then the part where they tell the truth like it is a cat that will leave if you try to pet it too fast.

I had never spoken in that room because it felt like trespassing onto a map that wasn’t mine. Tonight I raised my hand and let my father’s eyebrows do a dance and said my name and did not add the words those people say because they belong to their war. I said, “Sometimes I don’t know how to come back, and I haven’t even been anywhere,” and there was a small sound around the edges of the room that might have been humor and might have been breath and I kept going because if you stop mid-bridge you live there now. “I mean that there are days when I go to hand someone something and I fail them in a way that looks like dropping. I mean that I am trying to believe I am not magic in the bad sense, disappearing when I am needed and reappearing with nothing to show for the trip. I meet the people I love in a room and I think I did and then sometimes I worry I imagined it because nothing on the table knows my weight.” A man in a blue shirt with a postal logo on his breast nodded like he had seen my route before, and Beau smiled without making it about himself, and my father reached toward my shoulder and then moved his hand to the top of the chair like he was checking it for splinters. Vivian breathed the way she breathes when she is trying to memorize the inside of each of us.

After the meeting, in the parking lot lit by lights that always look like alien ships on the ground, my father said, “I didn’t know, honey,” and then shook his head at the hubris of that sentence and rephrased, “I didn’t know the shape of it. Thank you for telling me the shape.” He put a hand in his pocket and found his coin and then decided not to take it out and then took it out anyway and pressed it into my palm and said, “You hold it for me tonight. I can see it at your place tomorrow. It isn’t a test. It’s—we’re a team,” and I told him that a chip is a token and a token could be a key and yes, okay, I would put it on my windowsill and let the light touch it in his stead. Vivian kissed my temple and told me there was lemon in the soup and that this meant something about healing in some country and would I like a quart to take home, and I said yes because I am never too proud to accept soup.

On the way home, the air turned into a soft drum on the windshield again and the world smelted itself back into new. I took the bridge slow and looked at the river because I am superstitious and believe in water as if it owed me something just for having been my runway. The bridge lights made cardinal points on the black skin of it. A boy with no shirt ran along the far railing and I wanted to shout that he should go home and put on his mother’s worry like a jacket, but my windows were closed and maybe it was hotter inside than out. When I parked, a stray dog—gray with a white face like a saint—stood near the curb and lifted his head as if to ask me a question I didn’t know in the language for dog. He looked past me and then at me and then did that thing animals do when they smell who you are and how much you can offer and whether your hands are useful. He did not wag. He did not run. He blinked slow and then lay down with the patience of stone. I went inside with the coin warm in my hand and the soup armbreaking the bag and thought of how much the city knows and doesn’t say.

Mara called late from the hospital to say she had eaten a packet of peanut butter with a spoon like a child and that if she died of boredom first I had to write a scathing letter to management about how humans should be fed actual food, and then she told me about the old man who had taught her the Spanish word for roof while they waited for his daughter to bring his regular glasses, and then she told me she had dreamed of the pier again during her fifteen minutes in the nap room and that in the dream I had been there and then I had not been and that she woke up furious at me and then laughed at how the brain refuses fairness. I told her about the coin and she said, softly, because she respects the way objects carry heat, “Put it somewhere the morning can see it,” and I said I had put it where the sun slips its first question into my apartment. We were both quiet then, the kind of quiet that holds a shape like the donut of absence she had mentioned once about cartilage, the hole that makes the pastry. After a minute she said, “I thought of writing you a letter today, right in pen, in case the power went and we had to remember what hands are for,” and I told her she should write me a letter and she said, “Maybe I already did,” and then a voice behind her said her name and she said, “Okay, okay,” to the air and hung up in a way that promised we were not finished, just paused.

I began to keep a list at the back of my planner titled Experiments, not because I like science more than anyone else, but because calling something an experiment lets your fear sit outside for a minute like a neighbor smoking. In it I wrote: run water over hands and see if ring leaves line; press palm to mirror and count the seconds before fog; write name in lipstick on glass (wipe immediately); stand in sun and look for shadow with toe; ask Tasha to hand me something with eyes closed; eat a strawberry; light a match and blow it out. Some of these were too dramatic for my morning. Others were the kind of kitchen work women have always done in private, small tests to fold the world back into the right shape. I tried the strawberry and could not tell it from a tomato unless I watched the face of the person who had given it to me and borrowed their joy. I pressed my hand to the mirror and saw only the mirror waiting politely; later that week I did the same after a shower and the moisture made a print like a kiss and I cried because I wanted to shout I am here to the caulking. I asked Tasha to hand me the staple remover with my eyes closed and she did and before it reached my fingers I had to fight down the fear that it would keep going, that I would have to laugh like a woman who had fooled herself by setting a table for a guest who did not come.

At work, Mr. Boone’s son finally did show himself by accident, not in the office but at the sandwich place two blocks away. He was standing near the pickles looking like he had been sent by a casting agent to audition for the role of Bar Owner Who Makes Poor Choices. He had the Boone hair, a little too patient before it loses its will, and the Boone mouth, a little too ready to be a smile if you gave it half a reason. He was arguing lightly with a woman about the merits of mustard and then he saw me and turned off his voice like a radio and said, “You work with my dad,” as if this had been one of the facts he kept about himself to deploy at moments of emergency. I said I did and he made a motion like he meant to shake my hand but then shoved both of his into his pockets as if the hands had just remembered something. We made a small conversation because I am a person who can make a conversation the way some people can make an omelet. When I returned with my sandwich and told Tasha I had seen him she slapped the counter like she had lost a bet with herself. “An apparition,” she said, and then added, “Do not let him think we are as tidy as we are. It scares men like that.”

The following Sunday, Vivian held her soup night and invited neighbors who had never been inside our house to come in and make our living room look like a magazine about furniture that likes people in it. She made three pots because she believes in options as a moral principle and wrote their names on tape in her neat parochial school script: LENTIL WITH LEMON, CHICKEN RICE, MINESTRONE. My father wore a sweater that made him look like his own father in the photographs where regret is a kind of lighting. Mara and I stood in the kitchen shoulder to shoulder like line cooks and tried to finish each bowl with a flourish to convince people they were being celebrated. “Parsley,” she said, pinching it like a spell. “Salt,” I said, tipping the shaker like a wand. A woman with a baby named Lux asked if we were sisters and then gave me a look that said she had meant something else, and I told her the truth we had agreed upon, which is that love makes families and paperwork makes them legal and our two households have had both, and she smiled like that line was the right door to press.

After the guests left in a drizzle of thank-yous and the sound of spoon in bowl had transferred to a memory of itself, we did the dishes with the tired happiness of able people. Mara washed and I dried and Vivian flanked us with a towel brigade and my father cut the leftover bread in slices as if he had not been told he was the person in the room least qualified for knives. There was a song on the radio about a man who drives away and the woman who invents a reason to be mad at him to make the leaving easier, and Vivian turned it up while saying the youth of today think they invented yearning. Mara kept handing me wet heavy things and I had the sense again of being a person waiting for a ball that might pass through her hands. Once, without meaning to, I put my towel hand right through the gap between bowl and air and bent at the waist so fast I knocked my hip on the dishwasher. “Ow,” I said, not because it hurt but because the body requires narrative. “Careful,” Mara said, and then she touched my hip where it had no business hurting and left her hand there for the count of three and I had to put my free hand on the counter to steady to keep from doing that stupid thing of leaning back into her to pretend the world were simply physics and not longing.

Later, when Vivian had gone to bed with a book about a queen who did not apologize and my father had arranged his coins like a small country and kissed each of us like we were in a play about goodbye, Mara sat on the floor with her back against the couch and said, without preface as is her way when the thought is too true to dress, “Do you think something is wrong with you,” and it was a blessing that she did not say what because sometimes love is letting a person fill in the blank. I said, “I think something is different and the world hasn’t agreed to it yet,” and she nodded like a scientist who has heard the data and knows it doesn’t add but trusts the instinct that sent the search. She said, “Do you want a doctor,” and then made a face at the way she had said it as if doctors were a single creature in a case. “Not a doctor doctor, I mean, I could ask someone. Not for a diagnosis and a word that makes you smaller. Just an eye. Or we could do nothing and decide it will right itself, because sometimes I have found and it kills me that this is as true as the other truth that doing nothing is, often, what saved me from turning a bruise into a story,” and I loved her for knowing that medicine has a window for wisdom and for leaving the latch undone for me.

I told her I had been keeping a list and that I could show it to her if she promised not to laugh at the part where I tried to taste a strawberry with my eyes closed and she said yes and then laughed anyway in the kind way that makes the laugh part of your courage. I fetched the planner and sat with her on the floor and let her read it and she didn’t make a face except when she got to the mirror and then she closed it softly and put her hand, palm down, on the cover as though we were at church and I had sworn. She said, “I think you found the interesting thing about ghosts,” and then looked away like she had surprised herself with her own mouth. “Not the spooky thing. The part where they go to the same rooms again and again because those rooms know them and that is maybe part of how they remain. I don’t believe in them the way the movies do, with wet hems and malice, but I believe in the need that keeps them near. If I were a ghost I would live in a hospital sofa that sinks in the middle and not haunt anyone, exactly, just make sure everyone who sat there found their shoe,” and I told her she would be a very good ghost and she said, “Don’t make me a ghost,” and I said, “I won’t,” even though I knew that was not a promise anyone can keep.

After she left that night, I opened the window even though the heat begged me not to and sat at my little table and took out my ledger like it could be a net. The page was cream and made to be believed. I wrote the date and then, in the line I had started keeping for myself ever since I had noticed the spaces people leave for themselves are as important as the spaces they leave for others, I wrote, in my neatest numbers, I was here. The ink looked fine for a second and then gathered itself up into beads as if the paper had decided to be oil. I watched them wobble and then flatten and then wobble again like they had a soft mind. I pressed my thumb to the words and lifted it and there was no black on my skin. I blew on it as though it were a birthday trick. It dried eventually, obedient to the physics of office supplies, and I told myself that the humidity had gotten in, that the paper knew its climate better than I did, and then later I woke in the dark with the ledger in my mind like a person knocking on a door you forgot to lock.

At lunch on Monday, Tasha said she had been thinking of leaving in March, not leaving leaving, but leaving the office, and that she would drive as far as New Orleans or as far as she could afford to get gas and then she would sit in a cafe and write a letter to her mother in pencil because pencil makes even bad decisions look like drafts. She drew me a boat that took up the whole memo pad and put tiny faces in the windows and said, “Will you miss me if I go?” and I told her that missing is one of my primary languages and that yes, I would miss her in a way that would make me imagine her in every line at the post office and I would send her pictures of our blinking sign so she would remember the good and the silly. She said I could come with her and I said I was chained to spreadsheets by a gold chain and then she looked at me with that face she makes when she thinks I am making a joke to cushion a truth and said, “Take a day. Take two. Take eight. They will not know how to miss you but you will teach them,” and I said I would think about it in the way that means I would think about it like a rosary and probably say no because it was easier and I would be angry at myself for that ease and turn the anger toward something else, like the copier.

A postcard arrived that afternoon from California like the sea had spit it out on the exact person’s porch who would bring it to me. My mother had chosen a photograph of a beach that looks like a bruise, purple and yellow at once, and on the back she wrote, not Dear, but Deidre, and then crossed it out so thoroughly the paper thinned and wrote Dear D. and then wrote, “You would not believe these oranges,” and then drew three stars and a line that said she had met a woman who made jewelry from old silver trays and made a face out of forgotten spoons and wasn’t that as good a use for a life as any. There was more on the card about a man named Wally who read a poem once on the radio, and then a PS about how she had bought a postcard and then realized it had seagulls she didn’t like the shape of and threw it away and how did I feel about the word cormorant and whether it was too serious to be a bird. The address was almost ours. The mailman had penciled the correction in the margin. I held it and thought of fog horns like fathers who always stayed and of the way she had crossed out my mistake and replaced it with an initial like she had kept the door to my name not shut but just a little shy.

That night, I dreamed again about the pier. In this one, there were five of us, not four, which puzzled me because I could not count who the fifth belonged to, and then I realized it was lux, not the baby but the word, and the word made a sound when it stepped on the wood, and then my name came, not mispronounced this time, but breathed like a towel warm from the dryer. I turned and saw no one and then saw myself the way sometimes a mirror is a window until your face arrives. I woke with my tongue tasting of metal and fear and sat up too fast and had to hold the edge of the mattress like a ledge. The room wore its quiet like a shawl. The clock on the stove in the other room made that soft tick when it decides to show off that it came from a house with a grandfather in it. My phone blinked in the dark and I thought, dumbly, that a blinking object deserves an answer, and I reached for it and found that for a second there was an inch between reaching and finding, and that inch felt like a life you could live if you stepped into it.

When the sun finally gave up and slid back into the building and turned my coin to a small person singing, I wrote to Mara without the courage of morning coffee and said, “Let’s go again,” and then because I am a person who likes to give fate specific instructions, I added, “Not the Gulf. Somewhere with a meaner coastline. Somewhere that makes you stand up straight.” She wrote back in three tics because she is a quick study and said, “North Carolina,” and then wrote, “No, too complicated. Too many of my exes keep their secrets there,” and then wrote, “Oregon,” and then wrote, “I’m kidding. Too far unless we sell something,” and then wrote, “Cape Cod before the season ends,” and I typed back something about money and days and work and then I typed back nothing and then I wrote, “Pick the place you dream,” and she wrote, “Okay,” and then nothing for longer than I knew she could keep a thought from tripping over its own feet, and then she wrote, “I dreamed a stairway,” and then, as if translating herself, “Jersey.”

We are not the kind of people whose lives, when written down, look like maps worth bragging about, but there is a map in our heads of the way to Circle K and the way to the good park and the way to the hospital and the way to the interstate and now there would be a line from Arkansas to a shore the color of bottle glass and boardwalk pizza and men with tattoos that tell the weather. The idea of it felt at once tawdry and perfect, and I decided right then that I could be a person who goes to the wrong ocean in order to find her right one. We picked a weekend. We traded responsibilities like cards and made them sort themselves. Vivian clucked and then hid her smile in my hair. My father held his coin and counted aloud and said he would be fine if we left him and that he could cook for himself and that we both knew that meant he would eat cereal and peas. Tasha drew me a boat that said NE on a little flag and tucked it into my bag when I wasn’t looking and when I found it, later, it felt like permission folded small.

In the days before we left, I tried my experiments with more devotion as if I could get all my data in now so I’d have something to bring to the ocean. The mirror made a print on a Tuesday and refused on a Thursday and I told myself the glass was moody. The strawberry tasted like summer for exactly one bite and then like the memory of summer for the rest, which is not a bad thing if you are a person who likes memory. The staple remover obliged my fingers like an old friend. A child at the copy machine said, “Hey,” like I was a statue that had decided to speak. The cat—our cat, really, because he followed us when Vivian moved and now lives in both houses like a joint custody agreement—walked along the top of the couch and put his face in my hair and then took it out and sneezed and I took it as a blessing. I found the imprint of my palm in the dust on the top of my bookcase and wanted to put glass over it like a museum plaque. I went to the river and dropped a pebble and watched the circles make their solemn march outward and waited for the part of the ritual where you feel better and discovered that sometimes circles are just circles and that you have to do the feeling yourself. A man playing harmonica on the bank played the wrong song for the way the sky looked and I loved him for being wrong with such commitment.

The night before we left, Mara came over with a plastic bag that held a travel toothbrush, a tiny bottle of lotion that promised gold, and a tin of mints shaped like anchors. She put them on my counter and announced, “We will not buy any of this on the road and then we will discover we cannot do the thing we came to do for lack of a mint,” and then she saw how my face lifted into some kind of happiness and she took a breath and let it out like a person who has been given something you cannot wrap. She said, “I spoke to a doctor,” and when I made a face, she said, “Not your doctor. Not a doctor like that. Doctor Annabeth, who takes lunches at odd times and knows too much about X-rays and not the lay of the land of our specific bodies and therefore cannot say anything for sure except that people are stranger than the charts allow and that the world we know is made of the parts we can push against and the parts we cannot and that if you feel like falling through sometimes it could be your brain being a liar and it could be the floor being honest and that neither option is a character flaw,” and I stood very still because sometimes love speaks in paragraph and you have to hear all of it. I asked if Annabeth had told her to get me scanned like a suitcase and she said no, not yet, that she said to watch, to write down dates and times the way you are told to track a fever, to see if there was a pattern—sleep, food, weather, sorrow, the river’s mood. She handed me a little notebook with lemons on the cover that she had bought because she does not believe in making equipment so serious it scares the work away.

We lay on my bed on our stomachs like girls and looked at the map on my computer as if it were a joke telling itself well. I typed in directions from our place to a stretch of shore she remembered from her dream, which is not how dreams work, but if you make them behave like places sometimes they nod and comply. We decided we would go to the sort of motel that leaves a basket of coupons in the room and makes you feel like an aunt and an outlaw at once. We decided we would eat salt water taffy as if it were a sacrament and that we would not pretend we liked it if we did not. We decided we would walk out at dumb hours when the weather told us not to because we are people who do not like to be told. At some point we were both quiet for so long the phone screen went dark by itself and our two faces were in the black as if we were borrowing glass. I rolled onto my back and breathed and she clicked the phone back on not to check anything but so that the light would make it easier for us to keep speaking without naming the thing we were holding between us like a bowl.

When she left, I followed her to the door and watched her to the curb because I am a person who thinks distance is a trick and that you can tame it by staring. She turned once and lifted her hand and then put it down and then lifted it again because she is a person who edits even gestures. Down the street, the men under the flyover played something that had words like rain and I thought of the day when the sky would remember us as a pair and not as women trying to be good and I shut the door softly because if you slam it the house remembers.

I slept a lighter sleep, half full, the kind you do when you are about to move the scene. In the morning I would put the coin back in my father’s hand and he would pretend to complain about how warm I had made it and he would then put it to his lips as if to taste whether I had seasoned it different and he would do his little dance of superstition. In the morning, I would put the lemon notebook in the glove box like a secret and we would pull onto the interstate and become people with a purpose that could be written on a postcard without shame. In the morning, I would softly touch the ledger and the line I had made, and I would look for myself like a child checks behind a curtain and then I would say, out loud because seeing counts, I was here and I am going, and I would leave the light on for the person I might be when I returned.In the morning the light came in a tired way that made everything look as if it had spent the night up worrying. I put the coin on the sill before I made coffee and watched its edge catch the pale. It made a flash like a fish turning. At the sink I reached for the mug with the blue rim and found myself having to look twice to be sure I had lifted it; the clink against the counter was the proof. I wrote the date and the words I was here in the ledger with the carefulness of a person addressing a stranger and waited to see if the ink would behave. It pooled a little, not enough to be superstitious about if you are not me, and then it settled like weather. I wanted to write I am going but did not, because leaving feels like a tender thing that grows best if you don't touch it too much at the beginning.

When I drove to my father’s, he was already at the door like a boy waiting for the bus. He had on the sweater from a photograph again and his hand played with his pocket where he keeps his worry. Vivian called out from the kitchen for me to take the bag of snacks or she would chase me to the road barefoot and we both laughed because we had both seen her do exactly that for less. I handed him the coin and he tucked his head, and for a second he held it to his lips as if there were something garlic about it he could smell. “You warm it better,” he said, which is his way of telling me he is counting on me to have steadier hands than he thinks his are. Vivian kissed both of us like a woman packing fruit for a long journey and said, “Don’t be clever if the sign says don’t,” which is her way of telling me she remembers who I was at fifteen. On the doormat there was a damp leaf the exact shape of a tongue. The stray dog from the other night stood further down the sidewalk as if he had an appointment but was early. He looked at me in that seeing way that makes you feel both chosen and assessed and then he looked over me like rain looks over glass.

Mara pulled up in her car with the fish on the dashboard and thumped the horn once to say she was impatient in a playful way. She came inside to hug the people who have become her and accepted Vivian’s curse against hunger disguised as almonds and a bag of small oranges. My father told her not to let the tollbooth men give her counterfeit bills and she told him she could identify bone shards on a film the size of a postcard so she could probably tell a fake twenty. He said, “Keep an eye on her,” and jerked his head at me, and she said, very solemn, “Always,” and then made it into a joke by squinting one eye and holding her hand like a telescope. I slid the lemon notebook into the glove compartment and when I did I felt the car’s insides welcome it like an organism does a friendly graft.

The road did not care about our errands. It stretched and narrowed where it pleased, and the cities we passed wore their names like emblems and like apologies. In Memphis, the bridge made its rude arch and we sang Abba in a part of our range that is not flattering. In Nashville, every other station was guitar and brag, and Mara put on the fado to rinse us and I pictured an old woman singing into a fishmonger's dawn. We stopped at a station with a mural of a buffalo on the cinder block wall and a woman behind the counter who had four rings in one ear and wrote the total on the back of a receipt because the machine was sulking. I handed over a bill and held it longer than necessary so I could be sure this was a transaction and not a rehearsal; she took it with two fingers and looked up just left of my face and said, “You friends need anything else?” to the general space. Mara bought a bag of pretzels that promised lightning bolts of salt and a pack of those anchor mints and a magazine with a dog on the cover and a headline about ten ways to know you’ve been loved. In the car she tucked the mints into the cup holder and gave me one like a crumb from a host and watched while I put it on my tongue. It tasted like the shape of mint and then it did not. I told her it was perfect anyway and she touched my wrist in apology for making me take a test when I had not agreed.

We stayed one night in a place off the interstate that called itself a lodge and had a deer painted on the door. The clerk had a name tag that said JOSE with a little flag sticker next to it and he was on the phone when we walked up and he held up a finger for wait and smiled at Mara and then at the desk as if it had asked him a question. I leaned on the counter because my body likes to push against belonging and the counter did not notice. When he hung up he handed us one key like a person dealing cards deliberately and said, “Breakfast is from six to nine unless it isn’t,” which made me like him. Mara said, “Could we have two?” and he blinked as if recalculating and slid another across without quite making eye contact with me, like a newscaster reading serious words to the wrong camera. In the room the air smelled like rug and an old decision. The television said something about storms walking up the coast with their hands in their pockets. We lay on our separate beds and watched for a while and then turned the channels to a show about antique guns that had nothing to do with our world and then we shut it off and listened to the elevator in the hall take people up and put them down. I fell asleep with my shoe on like a dummy because sometimes my body sleeps as if it is sneaking in a nap it should not be having.

Morning dew made the car look like we had parked in a cloud. We drove and drove and talked and did not, because there is a way to spend hours with a person and never feel you are wasting time even when you say nothing that will be printed in a book. The closer we got, the flatter things went and the more the sky felt like a permission slip someone forgot to sign. The first smell of salt made Mara roll down the window like a teenager and laugh like a woman. It was not the kind Florida breathes, which is like a fruit market in a church. It was rawer and more medicinal, like the air had been cut with something that clears. Boarded-up shuttered motels announced VACANCY with only three letters lit. The T-shirts in shop windows said crabbing is not a hobby it’s a lifestyle and there were men in long shorts with old tattoos that looked like maps of rivers to no place. We crossed a drawbridge and pretend-fought about who was supposed to be steering the sky. When we pulled up to the motel with the name like a sailboat, a woman with a striped shirt and a lip the exact color of tomato paste slid our check-in form through a slot as if she were feeding the ocean a ration. She told us about pizza and she told us about saltwater taffy and she said the lifeguards were on a skeleton crew this late and that skeleton was on brand and then she looked at Mara and back at me like the ocean looks at two waves and knows they will pretend to be different.

We took the stairs even though the elevator had not offended us and when we reached the landing the wind pushed us back like a big aunt. The room had a bedspread with boats and a lamp shaped like a buoy and a basket of coupons that did indeed make me feel like I had been given permission to be quaint. We threw our bags and did that thing where two people in a room do a choreography that says I will take the left drawer and you will take the right and neither of us will say why that matters. On the balcony a woman in a sweatshirt that said WILDWOOD in a college font smoked as if to balance all that salt. The ocean threw its body at the shore over and over like a person trying to explain a point that has no words. Mara stood with her hands on the rail and said, “It’s mean,” and she smiled like that made her love it more.

On the boardwalk we ate the greasy good that was promised. The man behind the counter scraped the griddle like a violin and shouted numbers as if he was calling gamblers to their bets. We took a paper plate with a slice that incredulous New Yorkers would have judged for being broad and perfect, and we folded it and grease mapped my wrist and I tried to taste the basil and the acid and found that while I could identify their shapes with my mind, the sweetness of the tomatoes that everyone tells you to notice in stories was a blank hallway. We bought taffy because we are faithful to ritual, and the girl put it in a box with a picture of a couple from the 1950s who could have been anyone’s mother and father and were pretending to be everyone’s. We sat on a bench and put a piece in our mouths and laughed because taffy is an idea more than a flavor, and I thought: even if I could taste like I used to, this would still be what it is, an obligation you enjoy because it makes time move slower.
