I asked if Annabeth had told her to get me scanned like a suitcase and she said no, not yet, that she said to watch, to write down dates and times the way you are told to track a fever, to see if there was a pattern—sleep, food, weather, sorrow, the river’s mood. She handed me a little notebook with lemons on the cover that she had bought because she does not believe in making equipment so serious it scares the work away.

We lay on my bed on our stomachs like girls and looked at the map on my computer as if it were a joke telling itself well. I typed in directions from our place to a stretch of shore she remembered from her dream, which is not how dreams work, but if you make them behave like places sometimes they nod and comply. We decided we would go to the sort of motel that leaves a basket of coupons in the room and makes you feel like an aunt and an outlaw at once. We decided we would eat salt water taffy as if it were a sacrament and that we would not pretend we liked it if we did not. We decided we would walk out at dumb hours when the weather told us not to because we are people who do not like to be told. At some point we were both quiet for so long the phone screen went dark by itself and our two faces were in the black as if we were borrowing glass. I rolled onto my back and breathed and she clicked the phone back on not to check anything but so that the light would make it easier for us to keep speaking without naming the thing we were holding between us like a bowl.

When she left, I followed her to the door and watched her to the curb because I am a person who thinks distance is a trick and that you can tame it by staring. She turned once and lifted her hand and then put it down and then lifted it again because she is a person who edits even gestures. Down the street, the men under the flyover played something that had words like rain and I thought of the day when the sky would remember us as a pair and not as women trying to be good and I shut the door softly because if you slam it the house remembers.

I slept a lighter sleep, half full, the kind you do when you are about to move the scene. In the morning I would put the coin back in my father’s hand and he would pretend to complain about how warm I had made it and he would then put it to his lips as if to taste whether I had seasoned it different and he would do his little dance of superstition. In the morning, I would put the lemon notebook in the glove box like a secret and we would pull onto the interstate and become people with a purpose that could be written on a postcard without shame. In the morning, I would softly touch the ledger and the line I had made, and I would look for myself like a child checks behind a curtain and then I would say, out loud because seeing counts, I was here and I am going, and I would leave the light on for the person I might be when I returned.

In the morning the light came in a tired way that made everything look as if it had spent the night up worrying. I put the coin on the sill before I made coffee and watched its edge catch the pale. It made a flash like a fish turning. At the sink I reached for the mug with the blue rim and found myself having to look twice to be sure I had lifted it; the clink against the counter was the proof. I wrote the date and the words I was here in the ledger with the carefulness of a person addressing a stranger and waited to see if the ink would behave. It pooled a little, not enough to be superstitious about if you are not me, and then it settled like weather. I wanted to write I am going but did not, because leaving feels like a tender thing that grows best if you don't touch it too much at the beginning.

When I drove to my father’s, he was already at the door like a boy waiting for the bus. He had on the sweater from a photograph again and his hand played with his pocket where he keeps his worry. Vivian called out from the kitchen for me to take the bag of snacks or she would chase me to the road barefoot and we both laughed because we had both seen her do exactly that for less. I handed him the coin and he tucked his head, and for a second he held it to his lips as if there were something garlic about it he could smell. “You warm it better,” he said, which is his way of telling me he is counting on me to have steadier hands than he thinks his are. Vivian kissed both of us like a woman packing fruit for a long journey and said, “Don’t be clever if the sign says don’t,” which is her way of telling me she remembers who I was at fifteen. On the doormat there was a damp leaf the exact shape of a tongue. The stray dog from the other night stood further down the sidewalk as if he had an appointment but was early. He looked at me in that seeing way that makes you feel both chosen and assessed and then he looked over me like rain looks over glass.

Mara pulled up in her car with the fish on the dashboard and thumped the horn once to say she was impatient in a playful way. She came inside to hug the people who have become her and accepted Vivian’s curse against hunger disguised as almonds and a bag of small oranges. My father told her not to let the tollbooth men give her counterfeit bills and she told him she could identify bone shards on a film the size of a postcard so she could probably tell a fake twenty. He said, “Keep an eye on her,” and jerked his head at me, and she said, very solemn, “Always,” and then made it into a joke by squinting one eye and holding her hand like a telescope. I slid the lemon notebook into the glove compartment and when I did I felt the car’s insides welcome it like an organism does a friendly graft.

The road did not care about our errands. It stretched and narrowed where it pleased, and the cities we passed wore their names like emblems and like apologies. In Memphis, the bridge made its rude arch and we sang Abba in a part of our range that is not flattering. In Nashville, every other station was guitar and brag, and Mara put on the fado to rinse us and I pictured an old woman singing into a fishmonger's dawn. We stopped at a station with a mural of a buffalo on the cinder block wall and a woman behind the counter who had four rings in one ear and wrote the total on the back of a receipt because the machine was sulking. I handed over a bill and held it longer than necessary so I could be sure this was a transaction and not a rehearsal; she took it with two fingers and looked up just left of my face and said, “You friends need anything else?” to the general space. Mara bought a bag of pretzels that promised lightning bolts of salt and a pack of those anchor mints and a magazine with a dog on the cover and a headline about ten ways to know you’ve been loved. In the car she tucked the mints into the cup holder and gave me one like a crumb from a host and watched while I put it on my tongue. It tasted like the shape of mint and then it did not. I told her it was perfect anyway and she touched my wrist in apology for making me take a test when I had not agreed.

We stayed one night in a place off the interstate that called itself a lodge and had a deer painted on the door. The clerk had a name tag that said JOSE with a little flag sticker next to it and he was on the phone when we walked up and he held up a finger for wait and smiled at Mara and then at the desk as if it had asked him a question. I leaned on the counter because my body likes to push against belonging and the counter did not notice. When he hung up he handed us one key like a person dealing cards deliberately and said, “Breakfast is from six to nine unless it isn’t,” which made me like him. Mara said, “Could we have two?” and he blinked as if recalculating and slid another across without quite making eye contact with me, like a newscaster reading serious words to the wrong camera. In the room the air smelled like rug and an old decision. The television said something about storms walking up the coast with their hands in their pockets. We lay on our separate beds and watched for a while and then turned the channels to a show about antique guns that had nothing to do with our world and then we shut it off and listened to the elevator in the hall take people up and put them down. I fell asleep with my shoe on like a dummy because sometimes my body sleeps as if it is sneaking in a nap it should not be having.

Morning dew made the car look like we had parked in a cloud. We drove and drove and talked and did not, because there is a way to spend hours with a person and never feel you are wasting time even when you say nothing that will be printed in a book. The closer we got, the flatter things went and the more the sky felt like a permission slip someone forgot to sign. The first smell of salt made Mara roll down the window like a teenager and laugh like a woman. It was not the kind Florida breathes, which is like a fruit market in a church. It was rawer and more medicinal, like the air had been cut with something that clears. Boarded-up shuttered motels announced VACANCY with only three letters lit. The T-shirts in shop windows said crabbing is not a hobby it’s a lifestyle and there were men in long shorts with old tattoos that looked like maps of rivers to no place. We crossed a drawbridge and pretend-fought about who was supposed to be steering the sky. When we pulled up to the motel with the name like a sailboat, a woman with a striped shirt and a lip the exact color of tomato paste slid our check-in form through a slot as if she were feeding the ocean a ration. She told us about pizza and she told us about saltwater taffy and she said the lifeguards were on a skeleton crew this late and that skeleton was on brand and then she looked at Mara and back at me like the ocean looks at two waves and knows they will pretend to be different.

We took the stairs even though the elevator had not offended us and when we reached the landing the wind pushed us back like a big aunt. The room had a bedspread with boats and a lamp shaped like a buoy and a basket of coupons that did indeed make me feel like I had been given permission to be quaint. We threw our bags and did that thing where two people in a room do a choreography that says I will take the left drawer and you will take the right and neither of us will say why that matters. On the balcony a woman in a sweatshirt that said WILDWOOD in a college font smoked as if to balance all that salt. The ocean threw its body at the shore over and over like a person trying to explain a point that has no words. Mara stood with her hands on the rail and said, “It’s mean,” and she smiled like that made her love it more.

On the boardwalk we ate the greasy good that was promised. The man behind the counter scraped the griddle like a violin and shouted numbers as if he was calling gamblers to their bets. We took a paper plate with a slice that incredulous New Yorkers would have judged for being broad and perfect, and we folded it and grease mapped my wrist and I tried to taste the basil and the acid and found that while I could identify their shapes with my mind, the sweetness of the tomatoes that everyone tells you to notice in stories was a blank hallway. We bought taffy because we are faithful to ritual, and the girl put it in a box with a picture of a couple from the 1950s who could have been anyone’s mother and father and were pretending to be everyone’s. We sat on a bench and put a piece in our mouths and laughed because taffy is an idea more than a flavor, and I thought: even if I could taste like I used to, this would still be what it is, an obligation you enjoy because it makes time move slower. Birds hovered with their gangster eyes and made plans to snatch from toddlers. A child in a stroller stared at me and then did not. Mara wiped my wrist with her thumb without thinking and then stopped and apologized as if she had stepped too close to a ledge, and I said, trying to make the truth smaller than it is, “I like to be looked after,” and she said, “By me,” like a person checking the spelling of a difficult word.

In the afternoon, when the light went sideways and the families went in for naps and the boardwalk men put out their racks of hoodies like teeth, we walked to the stairs that go down to the beach. The stairs were wrong in the way that made them right. They had a bend on the third plank that made you put your foot down differently and a nail head that had risen to make a warning, and Mara put her hand on the railing and said, “This is it,” not loudly, not with drama, like how someone says they have found the street they grew up on by smell. The wood had that gritty skin that only boards near salt get. The wind made the flags go hard at the lifeguard chairs and the red cloth was the exact color of a decision you regret in a good dress. On the sand there were the usual armies of umbrellas with their spines showing and a man sleeping in a posture that would have meant sadness in another place but here meant simply sun.

I looked down at our hands, the way you do when you know that it's not appropriate to look at faces for too long, and I tried to see our shadows. Mara’s hand cast a neat double on the board. Mine did a strange thing. It shivered, not with the wind but with hesitation, as if the light could not make up its mind whether to be caught. I stepped forward to make a deeper shape and there was a smear and then nothing, the plank just itself again. It made my stomach go light in the wrong way. I stepped back. The board, the rail, the nail head, all were confident without me. I wanted to laugh because it is a joke the world plays often: how we think we mark things and how often they are busy marking themselves. I had that petty thought that maybe the angle is wrong and blamed the hour like a scold. Mara had crouched to tie her shoe with the grace she has with all knots. When she stood, she brushed my shoulder in passing and the brush landed like a moth, there, then gone.

We took our towels down because that is what women do even when we know we will not sit still. The water had that look of panes stacked at a diagonal, clear and then dark then light again, thick. We did not intend to swim, because the flags and because the lifeguard with the whistle blew at a boy trying to be a hero and because Mara’s mother lives in her like a lighthouse and flickers warnings at reasonable intervals. We rolled our pants and did the ridiculous ankle dance of stepping in and then out as if the ocean is a test you can fail on a minor scale and get partial credit. A wave reached up and touched me knee to knee and in that touch there was the smallest suggestion of thumb and forefinger again, a grip not cruel but instructive, and I had to plant both feet and tell my body it belonged. I scooped water and let it lick my palms; it had no taste. I put my tongue to the corner of my mouth to see if salt had chosen that place and found that the ocean could be sugar or snow and my mouth would not testify anymore.

The man with the whistle blew it for someone else. The women near us said their mother’s names as admonitions. Mara pointed with her elbow at the end of the pier that chewed its teeth into the water, and she told me that in the dream the board had been loose right there and she had wanted to fix it with her two hands and then she had woken with her fingers curled and the half-moon marks on her palm like a little secret alphabet. I said, “Let’s go look,” because looking is the human narcotic, and we went, not because we intended to climb it but because the angle from underneath shows you the structure of your fantasies. The barnacles were thick as an old truth. The pilings wore their skirts of weed like a fashion they did not ask for. A boy with a plastic net told us seriously that jellyfish had been seen near and to watch out for their invisible stings, and Mara thanked him gravely because she always thanks children as if they were diplomats.

We walked back to the towel and we sat just long enough to act like people who know how to idle. Then Mara stretched on her back and put her arm over her eyes and said, “If you were anyone else, I would tell you a thing," and I said, “Tell me a thing,” and she said, “If I tell you, it changes it.” I lay on my side and propped my head and watched the gulls do their petty crime. I thought about all the ways people confess love as if it were a crime, in whispers and with scans of the room; I thought of all the rooms where saying it had been the only clean act people could manage. I did not say the words that had sat in my mouth. I took out the lemon notebook and wrote down the time and the word downstairs and the words shadow hesitant and taste absent and then drew a picture of the pier like a child, which is to say the lines lied with love.

That night the motel hummed like a refrigerator even when the air conditioner had shut up. We ate at a place where the waitress said hon as if someone had handed her the word when she was ten and told her to keep it safe. The fried clams were a bruise, perfect in their rightness to the place, and I watched Mara savor each piece with an attention that made me feel religious. I drank a beer and it tasted like promises, which is to say more foam than substance, which is to say I liked it and then it left me. We went to the arcade and lost money on a game that required you to drive a car with a wheel that fought back like a bad memory. A girl in a sweatshirt offered to take our picture with the plastic shark's mouth around our shoulders and we said yes because when someone offers to domesticate a moment for you it feels unkind to refuse. She clicked twice. In the first, Mara looked like a woman who knows a joke about grief and I looked like I had been drawn in with pencil and then an eraser had passed over me gently. In the second there was a glare. The girl showed me and said, “Sometimes this phone hates inside light,” and we told her not to worry and then after she left Mara deleted none of them and let them sit like stones.

In the room we watched the weather again, because it is in us, in both of us, to want to know where and how things will go wrong and whether other people might be suffering in a way that can make ours feel connected. The man on the television said something about a system off the shelf, and the map made colors in a smear that looked like a child’s painting of a bruise and an angel. Mara brushed her teeth and then looked at herself in the mirror long and hard as if she were asking the person in there a question about courage. I turned off one lamp and then another and then turned one back on, because light’s job is to argue you into staying. On our separate beds we lay and talked until our sentences had gaps between them like planks over water, and sometimes neither of us stepped anyway and the gaps closed by themselves. When she said good night, she said it like a person being careful with something that could roll; when I said it, it sounded like a coin, bright and too round.

In the morning the air had a temper. People walk differently on days when the sky has its own business. I put the ledger on the bed and made the small account of our ordinary, what we had spent in dollars and in whatever else you spend on travel and on wanting. I wrote, I was here and also, ridiculously, I am trying, and then closed it in a hurry as if someone might see me being earnest and mistake it for weakness. Mara came out of the shower with her hair wet and her face lit in a way that was not only the bathroom light. She said she had dreamed again and that in the dream it had not been the board that was loose but the hinge in her, the place where you decide to step. She laughed at herself and called it melodrama and rolled her eyes as if to puncture it and then she put her hand on the adapted place between my shoulder and my neck where people put hands when they mean it and what passed between us felt like the solid version of that word I had been keeping wet.

We walked to the beach with our towels and our small bottle of a day’s courage. The flags stood their ground and the lifeguards had a look that says we will do what we can but the ocean doesn’t sign contracts. The stairway from the dream made its turn and we respected it. The water was louder than the night before. Sometimes the sea gossips; today it argued. A man in a yellow shirt jogged by with a dog that looked like a mistake and both of them were happy. A father built a wall with his small son that the next wave took with bored efficiency and the child cried as if he had not expected the obvious. Mara’s eyes were on the place where the water and the wood shake hands without respect. Her mouth made the line she gets when she is listening with the part of her that thinks in pictures. I stood next to her and could not tell if the nail head on the third board was higher or if I only wanted it to be. Sometimes you see signs because you need them more than you need facts.

We did the small cautionary things. We looked for ripples that suggest a current you cannot argue with. We decided to stand near the old woman with the visor because old women know. I rolled my pants again because I am a slow learner in matters of wet. A wave came in and made lace at our ankles and then another came in that was less lace and more sleeve. The sky had its mouth open so slightly that you could not call it anything but a breath. Mara said my name in that voice she uses when she is turning her head away from what she loves because she has to look toward work. “Deirdre,” she said, and it was a string thrown, and I looked at her and saw the tendons at her wrist like anchors, and then the wave that was not lace put its hand out and pulled.

It did not look like drama the way people tell it later when they want to be kind to themselves for not seeing it coming. It looked like an ordinary disobedience with ill manners. Her foot went from under, not because she is careless but because balance is a god with moods. She bent, the most human motion, not falling so much as adjusting. I reached. My hand did not meet her. It met the shape of her in air, and the air had its own good fidelity to itself. The towel at my shoulder slid and I took that stupid step, the one you take when you think the floor will move to meet you. The water came harder and made a rope around her knees and laughed in that heartless way the animate world has when it does not mean you. She shot me a look that was not panic, not yet; it was an equation—me plus you plus water equals—solve, solve, solve. I solved by holding my hands as if I knew how to make myself a hook. It is a special section of hell, discovering you cannot touch the person you have been trying not to love loudly. My fingers closed on nothing that the world would give me. It was like being asked to pick up fog and not offend it.

People were shouting. The lifeguard made his whistle into a knife. The old woman with the visor stood like a saint in a painting and said nothing because what could she say that would be better than a rope. Mara set her feet down and for a second that I will live in forever she was steadied. She held her hand out because she is a person who thinks of the simplest miracle first, and I put mine under hers because I am a person who still thinks miracles listen. The press of palm to palm that I had imagined a hundred times in rooms and kitchens and offices and at other people’s tables was a ghost’s joke. It landed light as thought and slid. We both felt the slide. She made a face that I have no name for because our inventory of expressions does not have one for this. It said this cannot be and also I am not surprised. She tried again because she is stubborn. I tried again because I have only so many moves.

The water did what it had set out to do without remorse. It is very likely that if I had been another woman, a heavier one, a more present one, a woman whose hand leaves sugar on the tongues of cups, I would have made a difference, and it is very likely that if she had been any other woman, she would have made the same mistake and we call it devotion. The wave that took a mouthful of her was not even a show-off. It was the mean thorough one that comes after the drama, that goes about its business and collects what the prettier wave left behind. It folded her waist and took her knees and offended gravity on her behalf. She went under with a look back that was not for me exactly but I took it that way because one day there would be no one else to take it. The ocean did not want her, not any more than it wants a bottle cap. It wanted motion. It wanted to prove a point it couldn't stop proving. The lifeguard went in with his straight back and his red float and another one followed and the people on the beach made that sound that crowds make, the sound that says we are the world and we are useless.

I stepped after, as if I had a right to participate in rescue, as if my body could negotiate with law. A man I did not know put his arm across me to stop me, the way you do in a car when the driver slams brakes and you play seat belt with your hand, and his arm felt like a bar even though I know very well it might not have been there. I moved around him because I am also stubborn and the water met me like a doorman who has been given very clear orders. It pushed. It pushed again. I understood that if I went further it would make a case against me. If I called her name it would not carry. I called it anyway. It sounded to me like when you knock on a hotel wall and there is a person next door you want to know you are there in case. The lifeguards made their angles. The one with the red float reached her shoulder and she came up and blew like a person who has been underwater for exactly long enough to tell a story later. The water receded to a moody line. It came back. It took more. It returned what it had to return. The world compressed itself to four bodies and a rope of foam.

Later, when we were on our knees on the towel and she was coughing in that awful animal way that makes you want to buy air in bottles to give it to people, she laid her hand on my forearm without thinking and her hand went right through the place where mine ought to have been and landed on the grit of the towel. She felt around like you do in a dark room for the pull cord, and we both looked at where our skin should have been together, and the look did not belong to any language I had. We sat that way as the men shouted rules at the sea and a woman prayed too loud and the boy with the jellyfish net explained to his father exactly what had occurred. The lime green on the lifeguard’s whistle looked shamefully cheerful. The sand under our knees felt like every grain was staring up and taking a note it would keep.

We tried to behave like the right kind of people. She let herself be examined on the sand by the men who have learned to kneel and say ma’am while they check your pulse. She nodded and followed their instructions to breathe slow like a practice. I wrapped a towel around her because towels are what we have and because that is the act we have been given in every tragedy since blankets were invented. She took it and smiled as if to tell me I had not failed to perform kindness and that in itself is a kind of kindness. The lifeguard said words about rip current and eyes open and not above your waist and I said, against the part of me that likes sarcasm, thank you. The old woman in the visor patted my shoulder and missed it and patted the air and did not seem to notice. Somewhere someone put their cooler down hard and made a sound that made me jump.

Back in the room, after the men had allowed us to leave because nothing was broken you could fix with a cast and because you have to let people go if they insist on going, Mara sat on the edge of the bed with the towel around her shoulders like a cape and the fish on the dashboard downstairs stared north. She coughed and then laughed and then cried all in the one breath, as if there had not been time to sort. She said, “Do not say it,” and I did not, and she said, “Say it,” and I did not. I crossed the room and stood in front of her and put my hands out and watched her put hers in mine and watched them again not catch. We both watched the not of it like a live thing between us. Her fingers closed on the air where mine had gone as if she were squeezing an invisible fruit and her mouth made a sound I had heard before in barns and kitchens and rooms with bad news; it is the sound made when the thing you already knew and would not say to yourself arrives with proof.

We stayed there too long for comfort, for sense, but sense was a door that had already shut. The tide kept shouting the same sentence outside in a language that doesn't accommodate apology. A siren far up the road did the ceremonial wail that communities insist upon as if it helps even when you cannot tell where to send your grief. Mara stood finally, because she is not a person who will be made into a patient without a fight. She peeled the towel off her shoulders as if she were taking her skin off and putting it back on, and she reached for me without eyes and found me not. She said my name the way you say a word when you are making sure it belongs to your mouth and then she said it again in the way you do when you are asking the room to answer. I made a decision to be the kind of person who says a true thing even if it makes the air colder. I said, “I don’t know how it’s going to go. I think I might not be the same kind of real as I used to be.” She nodded as if thanking me for putting a line on a map that already had roads.

We did the next simple things because the brain likes a list when the heart is roaring. We put her clothes in a pile by the radiator to tempt them to dry even though the radiator was cold. We wrung out salt from a shirt that had no reason to have so much in it. We took the lemon notebook from the glove box like a doctor fetching a file and wrote the time and the steps and what the water had said of us and how the towel had felt like a person when it was the only thing I could hold. We wrote in different hands and then read each other’s entry aloud like a prayer. We did not write the word ghost and we did not write the phrase almost family and we did not write the thought that some stories are jealous and want a clean tragedy to show at the end, because we are suspicious of clean anything when it comes to pain.

Outside, the storm the man on television had invited into our plans set its first foot down. The window glass went into itself with the sound of thin instruments. The people on the walk put their heads down and their shoulders forward because you can march through almost any weather if you pretend you are being paid. The sign at the motel office flickered VAC and then ANC and then nothing, and JOSE must have been thinking of his mother as he filled the lobby with the smell of coffee because buildings smell like the person in them who is trying. Mara stood at the window in the towel and watched the line of the sea like a person reading the heart monitor for someone she loves and cannot fix. Without thinking, because my body remembers what it has done even when it is losing its receipts, I stepped behind her and put my forehead between her shoulder blades and felt the heat of her that way without asking the air to broker. She did not startle. She reached back with one hand and let it hover where my hip would have been and left it there anyway. We stood like that for a long time, not moving, letting the weather do the noise for us, pretending that leaning is an action that can keep a person from being pulled.

By morning the storm had lost its theater and kept only the mess, a sulk of sea that slapped the pilings without showing off. We packed in the way people do when they are pretending a trip has simply ended and not changed its contract, each of us folding shirts into the same domestic squares we learned from our mothers as if neatness could unsnag the line. At the desk, JOSE had traded his flag sticker for a pumpkin pin that bobbed when he breathed. He slid the folio toward us and said the words he knew how to mean, that he hoped we had enjoyed our stay, that the taffy really is better at the shop near the kite place if you care, that the storm had been kind compared to the one three years ago that took the ice machine’s mind. Mara signed in the line with her careful print, and when I took the pen it was as though I had dipped it in water; the blue made a thin show and then receded into nothing, leaving the faintest gray suggestion of my name like a rumor. JOSE glanced down and then reflexively up, but his gaze did not catch my face; it slid to the left and landed on a stack of coasters advertising a beer the motel did not serve. He tapped the paper with his finger and said, “You’re all set,” to the air exactly where I had been standing and I thanked him too brightly and folded the receipt like something you tuck in your shoe for luck.

On the stairs the wind tried again to make us confess. It pushed against our knees and made the lemon notebook in the glove box press its spine against the plastic like it had a heartbeat. We drove with the radio quiet for a while and let the interstate say what it says to all travelers, that you may be anyone and leaving anywhere and that it will not ask your reason. At the first rest stop the automatic sink and I came to our understanding, which is to say it refused me outright and then, after I had moved my hands in front of its black glass eye like a woman trying to teach a bird a trick, it turned a thread of water on for half a second and shut it with a spasm of disdain. The paper towel machine watched me like a cat and did not purr. Mara stepped next and the sink gushed as if happy to recognize a regular; she dried her hands and looked at me with a kindness I did not want and at the sensor with a scolding I did. “We will out-stubborn you,” she told the metal, and the woman at the mirror with lipstick like a vow laughed, because sometimes other women will laugh with you when you choose your enemy and it is safe.

We made a new column in the lemon notebook called Machines, because even I like to see where the story repeats. Under it I wrote sink no, door if someone else walks with me yes, elevator yes, card reader looks me in the eye and shakes its head, microwave yes, scanner no, and then I drew a picture of the stall door latch because it had held when I asked it to and that felt like grace. On the road again the sky kept its gray in a pocket, letting out its light in brief folds, and Mara drove with her jaw set like a person who has chosen a pace and will not be bullied by the clock. Somewhere outside of Wilmington we played the game where you name houses as if they were dogs, white one with a porch is Petunia, the one with the tire swing is Huck, the brick with the glass block is Marge who makes lemon squares and pretends not to notice the money in the tin, and a small blue house that tilted slightly toward the road and looked game for anything was named Halfway because every trip needs a point to which you could return if you changed your mind.

In the part of the drive where roads become muscle memory and your body can leave your head alone for an hour, Mara said she had been thinking about a string. She said sailors, the old ones, kept a line between them when they went to the bow in weather, and that she had seen a picture once of two men with their jackets dark with rain tied to a mast like children to a story, and that she had thought it foolish and brave in the same breath. She said she was thinking about tying something to me the way you tie a key to a child’s belt loop on the first week of school. I told her I would wear any string she gave me and not for the metaphor but because my chest had begun to feel like a room without a doorknob. She reached into the bag of superstition between us and took out a scarf Vivian had shoved there because in every weather there is a draft, and she folded the scarf on her thigh with the care of a woman making a bed someone will be born in. At a long stoplight in a small town that had a barber pole and a thrift store that smelled like the afterlife of church, she looped the scarf around my wrist and then around hers and tied a double knot like a woman who has fixed a hundred pieces of machinery and knows which knot tells the truth. We sat for a minute in the ordinary binding of it and both of us watched our hands to see if they would obey. The light changed and a man in a dump truck eased past us with the patience of a person with nothing left to prove.

Back in Little Rock, the river lay down with the tired look of an animal after a sermon. I dropped Mara at the hospital even though she had told me not to, and we both acted surprised when the scarf fell between us like an undone promise. She went in through the volunteer door and the gray-haired woman with the clipboard smiled at her and then right past me in the same motion, and I had the childish urge to stomp my foot because sometimes indignation is easier than grief. I walked back to the car with the scarf in my hand like a leash and sat with my forehead on the steering wheel for longer than I meant to, until a man in a security golf cart tapped his horn twice, politely, to ask me not to be a hazard, and his face did the thing faces do when they see something they can’t set down, a flicker and then a smoothing, as if a hand had passed over the surface of him.

Vivian, when I came in, had her hands in dough and a radio on low telling her about the city in its best voice. She wiped her palms on her apron and came toward me with the body of a woman greeting her child and then she stopped, not because she had seen anything but because something in the air had made a slight change, like a key turned one element toward locked instead of open. She reached and then rubbed her forearms as if she had been cold and could not name why. I told her about the motel coffee and the sign and the sink and she blew hair out of her eyes the way a girl does, and she said she had a friend who had days like that after her daughter left for Montana and that the friend had started wearing perfume again just so something would remind the room to notice her. I told Vivian that if I wore a smell it would be probably soil or oranges and she nodded solemnly like choosing a scent was a contract with the self and said she had some oil from a woman at church who made everything smell like the inside of a good decision.

My father came home from his meeting with Beau with a new coin that he put next to the old one on the mantle like two brothers he was trying to force into friendship. He made a long story short, a skill he never remembers he has, and said a man had told a thing about losing the right to be the main character of your days and how he had learned to be grateful for it, and my father said he had almost stood up to argue and then had kept his seat and his mouth and that in itself was growth and a miracle both. He took my face in his hands, which is his chief indulgence, and then he paused and looked at his palms and laughed at himself for checking whether I had left something there like glitter, and he kissed my forehead anyway and told me that I was, in the words of Beau, in the middle of a story and that the middle is the puddle of it and the place you mistake for the end. I could have kissed Beau, saint of middle parts, right then and there for giving my father that sentence to hand me like a cup of water.

At work, the office had the dignity of a person who has been through a storm and put her hair back up. The blinking sign still stuttered but it was a friend’s stutter. Tasha had indeed spun my chair and it had the faint smell of impulsive perfume, which I told her made it sit better. She kissed the air at me and then stopped, because her body is wise, and she said, “Permission?” and I said yes and we bumped shoulders like birds. She did not say the word ghost or any of its cousins because she is a woman who knows a word can call a thing to the table like a summons. She gave me a file labeled CALDWELL, SIGNAGE in her neat fifth-grade teacher letters and then whispered that Mr. Boone had asked about the ocean and she had told him it was wet and he had laughed like a good man. When he came to my door he put his hands in his pockets and looked at the floor first, a habit of his that I am fond of because it means he is about to try to be kinder than he knows how. He said he had decided he was going to start coming in on time just to see what would happen to the fabric of the world. I told him it would snag and then mend. He told me his son said hello, which I doubted, and that the school board woman with the neon shoes had called and said their auditor had cried in the supply room, which I respected, and then he asked if I wanted to take a Wednesday to not be here and I told him the truth, which is that I want to but wanting does not always move me.

Teague, with his folds of fabric and his adjectives, came to show me the new mock-ups and stood in the doorway like a man posing for a portrait of a person who sells signs. He did not call me Deborah and I decided to count that as victory. He laid the papers on the desk like cards and tapped a corner and said he had taken my note about the barbecue place wanting to look like it knew how to forgive you for leaving and that he had tried a font that looked as if someone’s uncle had a steady hand in 1978. When he lifted the top sheet the next one stuck as if by wet, and he said, “Huh,” and then smiled his salesman smile at the air as if it had considered buying. “Static,” he said apologetically, and I nodded as if its name calmed me, and he reached to separate them and his fingers went perfectly through the margin my hand had made a moment earlier. He jerked back and made a joke about the paper being sharp and I let him have it, because sometimes everybody deserves a soft lie.

Because I am not brave but wish to be, I took a bus after work to the hospital to find Annabeth, who has a badge that says DOCTOR in the way you put a bell over a word to make it understood. She has hair like a hymn and a laugh with the bark still in it, and she looked at me the way people look at a painting they haven’t learned to love yet and plan to, respectfully, with a little apology. She did not check my reflexes or ask me to count backward by sevens or draw a clock, though she told me what other people would ask and I thanked her in advance for skipping their script. She asked instead what the machines say yes to and what they deny, and she asked when it is worse and when the world sighs and lets me in, and I said, surprising myself, that it is worse when I am about to say a thing that would rearrange the furniture of a room and that it is better when I am giving someone change for a ten at a fundraiser and miscount by accident and everyone laughs. She nodded like I had offered her an interesting flavor. She said that some brains take you out of your body when there is a lion, and that some decide there is a lion when there is love, which is another kind of catastrophe, and that sometimes this is a trick you can learn to take apart with breath and a word and sometimes it is the world’s trick and then your job is to carry it like a bowl. “You are not broken,” she said like a person telling a child that their shoes will do fine. “You are not a magician, the bad kind. And even if you were, I have met a great many women who exist only slightly and you are not one of them. Where can you feel yourself the most?” she asked, and I thought of the place where my head meets my neck and of the way sound catches under the sternum like a moth and I told her the truth, which is that my voice does not betray me.

Mara came at the end of the day in her scrub top and tired shoulders and brought me a small machine wrapped in a towel like a baby. “It’s a thermal thing,” she said with the glee of a person who knows a toy might save the world. “We use it for the engine room,” she added, as if hospitals had those, and I put my hand up like a child in a schoolyard and she took the camera and aimed and showed me the bloom of my neck, the heat at my chest where my heart insists, the cool at my fingers that surprised her and did not me. She aimed at my palm and I watched the colors make their appeal and I felt like I was watching a weather map of a place I had visited and could not recollect the details of. “You see?” she whispered, not because anyone was asleep but because we have both begun to whisper when we get too close to naming. “You are not nothing. You are noise. The good kind.” She took a picture of the cat as he walked in like a mayor and he made a glorious flame. He paused by my leg and hesitated, which is his version of affection, and then rubbed his head against the couch instead and threw me a look as if to say that everyone is complicated and he has decided that is the only fun we get.

We tried the scarf experiment the next night in my apartment because I decided being foolish is better done at home. We tied it from wrist to wrist again and lay on the floor like girls reading magazines, only one of the magazines was the lemon notebook and the other was a back issue of a medical journal that had a picture of a spine like a sea creature. We pulled gently, left then right, and when I closed my eyes and let her move me I felt the tug like the smallest approval and something in me unclenched and I laughed and then cried in the same breath, which is my version of the body taking off a sweater. She kissed the inside of her own wrist where the knot lay like a charm and I pretended she had kissed mine and was pleased with the pretending because sometimes make-believe is the only way to cross a street. We fell asleep like that, wrists cinched, and woke to find the scarf coiled on the rug with the petulance of objects that have been asked to sustain something they were not designed for. The knot had slipped toward her and off me as if the night knew how to rearrange the narrative. She made a sound that was not disappointment and not anger. It was recognition.

Tasha, because she understands the value of loud, took me to a karaoke place on a Thursday and stood me in front of a microphone that smelled like every mouth it had ever met and said, “Sing badly,” which is her version of a blessing. We picked a song about standing in a kitchen at midnight and we did not hit any notes that would hurt a dog and the men at the bar watched the game and not us and the woman with the baseball cap cried at a line we did not mean to underline. The machine did not doubt me. It turned my voice into paper and then into air and I could feel the way the sound bent around the room and came back to my ribs. I watched myself steam in the cheap light like rice and I wrote that down later in the lemon book because it felt like news, that you can be believed by your own mouth. When we came out into the dark a man with a trumpet on a bicycle rode by and let the instrument cough once as if to say this is an option, too, and I laughed like a person who has been chosen for a minor miracle and plans to tip well. Tasha twined her arm in mine, then pulled away deliberately and looked at my face to make sure she had not offended, and I told her silently with my shoulders that she had not and with my mouth that I am still practicing.

Days began to sort themselves into categories that I refuse to make into a calendar because the minute you give something a name it asks to be called for supper every night. There were sink days and ledger days and days when numbers slid into their columns like swallows finding the right garage. There were mornings when the coin my father gave me warmed in my palm as if it were alive and days when I could not get it to change temperature at all and I told myself the apartment was simply a colder place than it felt. There were afternoons when the cat took pity and sat near me and arranged his small thunder on my shin and I wept because animals are economists and do not give what does not have use. There were evenings when Mara fell asleep in my lap and then startled when her head met the arrangement of cushions I had made to keep it from dropping to the floor, and her apology for waking was also an apology for the condition neither of us had asked for and she performed it with grace and the joke she has for sorrow: that it is neighborly to both of us and therefore should be brought mac and cheese.

The ledger misbehaved one night and then obeyed the next and I decided that paper is moodier than we allow. I bought a pencil because I wanted to make the world argue less and its lead did what lead does, wore itself down with service. I pressed the letters of I was here with more force than is required for such small words and when I finished the indentation showed on the next page, an embossing of evidence. I liked the idea that the future had already been bruised by my insistence, and I told that to the ceiling because sometimes you have to accuse your roof of complicity. The mirror in the bathroom fogged only at the edges when I breathed and sometimes not at all and I learned to take comfort in the shower because the steam did not lie; it rushed and coated and made me part of weather, and if that is all I am allowed then I can be good weather.

We went to my father’s together on a Sunday when his poker men came by to pretend to care about cards and to care very much about pretzels. They dealt as if they were inventing the deck and told stories that sounded like each other because that is how men keep safe in groups. My father told none of his candle story out of respect for the fresh faces and laughed at the right places with his mouth and not his hands. Vivian handed out bowls as if she were crowning each man with the right to keep living and their eyes softened as spoons met soup. Mara sat on the floor between my father’s chair and the coffee table and in the middle of someone’s long-ago baseball she put her hand out and I, idiot, put mine in it and we both watched as our longtime trick disappointed us. She did not pull back. She kept her hand there, in the space where mine had meant to be, and she closed her fingers and she breathed and I did the same and to anyone watching we looked like ordinary women making a small ordinary pact. My father’s eyes found us because the animal in him keeps us both and he smiled in that wide way like a prayer answered he cannot repeat aloud because it would get hurt by being said, and then he looked away deliberately in the way of people who understand that privacy sometimes is the only way to keep a thing alive.

Night came like a slow good songwriter and the city pressed itself into its familiar shapes. I dreamed I was under the pier and that I could see up through the boards to the shoes of people who thought they were alone and I reached for their laces not to trip them but to tell them I was there. I woke with salt on my lips that was not taste but the memory of it and found the scarf coiled again near my wrist because I had tied it in my sleep without knowing and that felt like hope disguised as clumsiness. In the morning Mara texted me a picture of the skeleton of a leaf she had found on the hospital sidewalk and she wrote, This is what happens when the world takes everything but the shape, and I wrote back, What if shape is enough, and she wrote, Sometimes.

The next week held itself together like a cake that threatens to fall if you open the oven and we did not open it. I went to work, I went to the meeting in the basement with the chairs and the coffee that tastes like having tried, I went to the river and watched a man teach his son how to throw a line without catching his own ear, I went to the store and chatted with the cashier who always asks me to bless her even though I am an atheist with good manners, and the automatic door at the pharmacy did not open until a woman with a stroller approached beside me and then it flew back so fast the air kissed my arm as if to apologize. If there is a god watching over those doors, he has a sense of humor and a poor understanding of timing. I put these things in the lemon notebook as if bullets could pin down the air and the act of placing a dot at the end of a phrase could nail it to the day.

On Friday, because we had decided not to be bullied entirely by fear, we drove out to the lake to practice a different kind of water. The Arkansas does not speak the language of Jersey and I wanted to hear our dialect again. We stood on the bank under a sky that had pressed its iron and waited for the place where water coaxes stone to confess. I stepped in up to my shins like a person who has not learned and the chill made my teeth report. Mara held my elbow not because it would help but because sometimes pretending is the only bridge you get. A boy with a stick pretended to be Moses and the water obeyed him only as much as it must a child with an Old Testament in his grin. When we left, we were damp and we were not undone, and in the lemon book I wrote, lake easier, and the little check mark I drew after it felt like the first yes I had earned in weeks.

That night I took the coin from the windowsill where the morning makes a habit of finding it and put it in my mouth like a wafer. It tasted like a thing that has been in the hands of a man who keeps choosing and that was both iron and bread. I placed it in my father’s palm later with ceremony and he pretended to scold me for drooling on dignity and then he slipped it in his pocket and patted it like you pat a child who has made a plan. Walking home I saw the stray dog again, the saint with his white face, and I crouched and offered him my hand without anticipation. He came forward without haste and sniffed and blinked and then laid his chin for a second in the air where my fingers had meant to be, and that is something no machine can do, and I stood up with him and we both looked down the street to where the flyover men were playing a song that had a new refrain and neither of us needed the words to know we were meant to keep moving.

The next morning I decided to be loud in the ways that were still permitted. I put on a skirt the color of tail lights and bracelets that made opinions when I moved my wrists. At Freda’s I asked for flour, just a pinch, and told her I was trying a recipe that might be improved by superstition. She cupped white onto my palm as if it were holy and said, “Now you’ll leave a trail,” and I pressed my hands together, two prayer books, and clapped once over the counter on purpose so the dust would rise and drift toward the window where the heat writes its letters. Her niece laughed at the cloud and a child in a dinosaur T-shirt turned and said, “Snow,” to no one in particular. I left two finger marks on the door handle and felt a childish pride, as if I had signed a guest book in a language glass understands. Outside, a boy clipped my elbow with his scooter and said, “Sorry, ma’am,” to the space just over my shoulder. I told the air it had been forgiven and the air took its time to run the message to him.

Back at the office the school board arrived with their neon emissary and a florist’s worth of anxiety. The young woman with the shoes, whose name turned out to be Keely, stood in my doorway with a box of donut holes and an expression you might bring to a veterinarian when your cat has done something unspeakable to the rug. Behind her came the auditor, a woman whose hair had been forced by humidity into a halo she did not want and whose eye makeup made it look as if she had not slept since 1996. She introduced herself as Ms. Kent and shook the air where my hand was, briskly, efficiently, like a person who has learned to get through a day by making it into tasks. Her voice was the kind that makes you confess how you arranged the petty cash even when you did it ethically. We took them to the conference room. Mr. Boone came in with his tie obedient and his son’s ghost hovering near him in the lack of it, and Tasha placed a pen at each chair as if we were about to sit a true or false about our souls.

The numbers did that thing numbers do when they know an audience is not charitable; they threw shadows and invented mysteries. Keely’s foot jittered to a song only she could hear and Ms. Kent stacked and restacked the same three pages until it looked like she was building a small city she might then knock down for revenge. When Ms. Kent stepped into the hall and caught herself, unprofessionally, tears pricking like freckles, I followed with my voice ahead of me. I told her about the freezer room at the hospital and how Mara moved stalagmites from one socket to another during storms as if they weighed nothing because need lightens. I told her about how numbers are like cats; they will sit in your lap if you don’t stare at them directly. She laughed against her will and wiped the underside of her eye with the edge of her wrist because she was wearing mascara and I have learned that women will risk much but not stripes down their cheeks if there is a choice. She thanked—something—for the story. She did not turn toward me, exactly; she bowed toward the corridor in my direction like a person acknowledging good lighting. When she went back in she made a generous decision about a column that could have been argued either way. Keely offered me a donut hole in celebration and I accepted it because there are days you take a sphere of fried sugar like communion and it absolves you for five minutes.

At lunch, Tasha put her shoulder against the door frame and confessed that she had been offered a job at a place with plants on desks that were watered by schedule and a policy about dogs on Fridays that read like a marriage vow. “It’s in town,” she said, as if telling me the town would keep us married, “and they promised to let me be weirder than is safe.” I told her to take it, because I am a woman who has learned that pushing people out of cages is not disloyalty. She said she hadn’t decided, which means she had, and I drew her a boat on the back of a folder while she talked about health insurance and the smell of new carpet and the emotional temperature of managers who use the phrase my door is always open. The mast went straight all by itself without my will. When I showed it to her she put her thumb on the hull and pressed until the paper dented like a shoreline. “That’s the place,” she said. “If I go, I’ll leave you my stapler,” and I told her I wanted her laugh more.

We made an attempt at dinner that night as if a meal might be a test you can pass. Mara brought lemons that she pressed with a small tool shaped like a bird and I roasted a chicken with the ridiculous confidence that comes from recipes that call for salt and time. We ate, in the way the middle class does, with gratitude that sits in the room like a good friend. I tried to taste. The acid announced itself like a thin woman with a megaphone. The chicken had its human warmth, the fat ready and the skin adequate, and everything that used to be a delicate balance struck me as a set for a play I had once been in and forgotten the lines to. Mara watched my face with a look that always makes me braver and worse. “Tell me,” she said, and I told her that the lemon tasted like the idea of lemon, the way a postcard is the idea of a place if you’ve never been. She tore her piece of bread with those strong fingers and said, “I can feed the part of you that still eats ideas,” and then smiled like a woman who knows the scale of promises and is not afraid of that math.

On the walk after, the sidewalk was a seam the city had been too busy to tighten. A crew had left a square of wet cement under a small fence, four little metal legs like a child’s playpen. Without making a plan, we both wanted our hands there. We dipped fingers like thieves, the way every mouth wants to lick frosting if invited. Mara pressed her palm, sure, leaving a whorl you could probably use to open her accounts. I pressed mine and watched the gray accept the gesture politely and then shrug. Two faint commas where my ring and my bone might leave a thought, no more. A woman in a visor pushing a stroller, as if they are a species proliferating, smiled at us and said, “Your children will love finding that in twenty years,” and Mara said, “Yes,” confidently, even though we have not decided whether children belong to our plot line. I put the lemon notebook on the driver’s seat later and wrote, cement says maybe, and I liked that as an answer better than no.

Annabeth met me again on the corner where the hospital breathes out its nests of parking and told me a story about a man whose arm had decided it belonged to someone else. She told it gently, with no relish for the freakish. She said, “The brain is a trickster and also the kindest nurse you ever had. Sometimes it cuts feeling so you can pass through a particular hour. Sometimes it leaves you in the room and takes the heavy box down the stairs without telling you so you think you are lazy for not helping. Sometimes it tells the world to stop touching you because you have not consented for a long time.” We walked slowly and counted the way the automatic doors agreed to respond to Mara, then to me. She watched my face when I used my voice to announce myself to the metal and the glass, saying “hello” to a door like I was arriving at a cousin’s. The door behaved perfectly and Annabeth reached to take my wrist and then converted the reach, practiced now, into a gesture near my sleeve. “We will build a stupid toolkit,” she said. “Perfume, bells, high color, the manner of a woman with a complaint. Your voice most of all. Your voice hooks in.” She told me to go into the stairwell and sing a little. I laughed and did it. The echo hugged me the way a church does if you do not owe it money. When I came out a janitor with a scent like pine in his collar said, “You made that landing nicer,” to the wall, and I decided I would take compliments where they fell.

There was a day at the crosswalk when the sun believed itself a benevolent king and I stepped out with my stack of papers and confidence and a car did not slow because the car did not have brains for me. My own brain did what it had been practicing; I said my name in the middle of the street like you say amen and the driver, a woman my mother’s age with a visor and good lipstick, startled like she had seen a deer on hind legs and braked. She put her hand to her heart in the old gesture as if to make sure it was still in attendance. I bowed to her like a clown at the end of a cheap trick. My knees waited to shake until I had made the opposite curb. I wrote in the lemon book, crosswalk voice wins, and underlined it, and made a little star as if I had earned a badge.

At the meeting in the basement with the coffee that warms you by guilt and then by love, Beau nodded at me the way a man nods when he is asking without asking. I said a few words because my father’s shoulders had lifted into their set of please hear me and I wanted to meet him. I spoke about machines the way a child speaks about weather, too seriously and with one secret. I said that sometimes I feel like the stamp the notary uses at work has been lifted from the desk and no one knows where to put it down, and a woman three chairs away whose hands were knitting a vague blue made a sound that said she knew that landscape. After, my father hugged me full and hard and then let his hands slide to the edges of my sweater as if making sure the sweater had obeyed gravity. In the parking lot with the saucers of light we all love like UFOs, Vivian pressed a small vial into my palm that said orange blossom on a label in a woman’s hand. “Try this,” she said. “It makes the house remember me when I come in, and I tried a million before it didn’t make me feel like whoever was wearing those magazines in the 80s.” It smelled like a church married to a grove. I dabbed it behind my ears and on my wrists and startled myself later when I turned my head fast and the air came with me.

When Tasha told Mr. Boone she was taking the job with the plants and the promise, he surprised us both by leaning back, looking at the ceiling with affection, and then standing to hug her like a man who has read a pamphlet about appropriate workplace boundaries and decided to take the risk in the name of human decency. He said, “You’ll ruin them in the best way,” and she said, “I know,” and then she cried in my office not like a woman leaving but like a woman arriving somewhere that required a toll she had saved up for in jars. We spent her last hour drawing boats with serious masts on memo pads and leaving them under staplers and in drawers for the future to find when it needs directional signs. When she left that day she took the stapler and wrote me a note that said, I will staple the sky, which is nonsense and also what you want someone you love to threaten.

Mara had been asked to present a thing at a small conference in Wilmington about exactly the machines she loved and cursed. “It’s hardly anything,” she said, “just me saying that organization is not a personality flaw,” and I told her to call it what it is, a miracle. I pretended I had a choice about whether to go and she pretended we could be prudent and we both did that adult dance until we tripped over the truth. We booked a cheap hotel with carpets that looked like the idea of weather and a broken chalkboard out front that still promised a continental breakfast even though the chalk no longer took. My mother sent a postcard from California that week with a drawing of pelicans arranged like comets and she wrote my name correctly and then underlined it as if to see how it looked, and in the corner she scrawled, “Do you ever think how much of life is waiting in halls?” and I wanted to call and say yes, but I don’t know what you waited for, and also to ask her whether pelicans still stole lunches right off blankets. I pinned the card to the cork board with a pushpin that bent like a tired person and thought of her in fog and me in our heat and Mara near a storm line and all of us trading weather like recipes.

The night before we left I took the orange blossom and dotted the inside of my scarf and the inside of the jacket I wear when I want to be taken seriously and the hem of the T-shirt I sleep in because I planned to take it off and put it in Mara’s bag. She watched me do it and I watched her watch me and there are entire marriages built on such small ceremonies. We made tea because that is what you do when you have decided to leave a place for a place that has water plotted against you. The kettle sang, as kettles are generous enough to do, and I poured and tasted nothing and tasted everything because the smell put a cloak on the nothing. We sat on the floor with our backs against the couch, our knees up like children making forts, and went over the list of simple weapons: voice, color, scent, the name of a person said in the room like a claim. “And if all else fails,” she said, “I will tie you to things,” and I told her I was starting to find it sexy, which made her laugh that laugh that has saved me from five different cliffs.

We left before the traffic learned how to be cruel and the road offered itself up in long gray scrolls. The strangeness of travel is you become more yourself and less at the same time. The automatic soap dispensers at the first stop offended me and then relented and I curtsied to the paper towels because you may as well thank the gods for their crumbs. In the car, the lemon notebook’s pages were beginning to have that dog-eared look of devotion. Under Machines I added, hotel key card works if someone else tries first, and under People I put, cashier called me hon to the air and it warmed me anyway. Mara drove the way she always does, like a pilot making decisions no one else sees, and sang along to a woman with a voice like rope and violets. We crossed a stretch where the land had been shaved down to bones and the horizon made a solemn promise and kept it. When we arrived, the hotel smelled like last week’s rain and a bowl of apples that was not actually there.

Her talk was in a room with carpet trying to be a forest and chairs that resent their bolts. She set up her slides, which were the careful kind that do not wrestle an audience but lead them up a path by the elbow. I sat near the back with a Styrofoam coffee that tasted like all the churches in America and watched her make a room unlazy. She said the names of machines the way other women say the names of children into microphones and she did not pretend to like any of them more than they deserved. After, a man with a tie that had too many opinions said something about algorithms and she managed to be kind and precise at once, which is her knife work. A woman in a green cardigan asked a question so gently it was almost a confession and Mara answered like a balm. When the applause came it sat down properly, not overeager, the better sort of appreciation. By the snack table a person trying to keep the grapes from rolling into the cookie platter asked me if I had enjoyed our keynote and I said yes and wanted to say more and did not because explanation always costs a toll.

We walked after, because if there is a body of water within a mile Mara will negotiate me toward it without me noticing. The Cape Fear wore its bad name with class. The air had salt in its breath even upriver. A man on a bench played a guitar with only five strings and still found us a song. The pier had planks that had listened to more stories than wood should be asked to hold. As we stepped, the light took on that drama school quality it has near closing time. I watched our shadows again because once you begin you cannot stop. Mine did not go missing, not entirely; it limped, then thickened, then refused, like a friend who will not come to your party and then does at the last minute with a casserole. Mara took my hand in the way you will if you have decided to stop being careful, and for a moment her fingers warmed the place my fingers would have been as if heat still obeyed the old rules. It was not the cinematic moment where everything snaps into a lesson. It was two women with a lemon notebook and a scarf and a past and a river and a promise and a cliff.

That night, in the bed with the rustle of sheets that have been laundered out of their softness, I said the sentence I had been rehearsing for months in my mouth. I said it in the dark because truth looks less formal in the dress she sleeps in. I told her that I loved her and that it was the kind of love that felt like a tide chart I kept folded in my purse even when the river behaved. When I had finished and there was the space afterwards where the air decides if it will give you back what you have pressed into it, she reached for me and her hand passed into the heat by my shoulder and came back with nothing but proof. She said my name very softly, a way I had not yet heard, the way people say a country when they have finally crossed its border. She said she loved me back, and I saw the word go into the room and put its lamp down and open curtains. We kissed with fabric between us, my foolish scarf and her mouth and mine, the way children play marriages in school with mittens and veils borrowed, and it was ridiculous and decent and I would have married the absurd right then for the service it provided. Beneath the cloth I could feel her breath and hear the small noise she makes when her heart permits joy, which is an animal sound, not a word. It anchored me better than any belt could.

In the morning the hotel breakfast was a democracy of carbs and two apples that had seen things. We took a cinnamon roll to the river and tore it like sisters in a fable and fed the gulls even though a sign asked us not to because the sign had no gulls to scold. The sky had the posture of a person on the edge of deciding if they would leave the party. Mara tipped her head back to let the wind lift her hair and then squared her shoulders because she has never been good at letting weather be in charge. “One more walk,” she said, and we went to the ferry steps where the river pretends to be a road. The boards there had been worn to language. A man in a shirt that had been white told us to watch our feet because the splinters had made a union. We watched. We walked anyway.

On our way back, a child with a balloon shaped like a fish let go because the sky is better at invitations than parents are at warning. The fish went to its god and the child made the sound children make when they have lost a kingdom. Mara started to run without thinking because she is the kind of woman who thinks she can persuade physics by argument. I called her name the way I have learned to call it when I am at the edge of the street and the cars have not agreed on me yet, and she stopped and turned and the balloon was already on its way to the afterlife of latex. The mother thanked a radius of people and the mother’s friend adjusted her visor and the child hiccuped like a broken metronome. We walked on, our shadows behaving within acceptable error margins. The lemon notebook had its new page waiting and I put, ferry boards said yes, and then I wrote it again because repetition makes a thing truer to me, even if it annoys other people.

On the drive home the rain decided we were not to be tested further and let us keep the dry. Somewhere past the state line the stray dog crossed my mind like a benediction and I said it out loud without meaning to. “The saint,” I said, and Mara said, “Which one?” and I told her about the white face and how he had put his chin where my fingers would have been and she said, “That is how I plan to love you when it all is its worst,” and we both sat in that sentence like a pew and let it do its job. When we got back to the apartment, the coin on the sill flashed once at the last light and I touched it with my mouth again because I am foolish and crave metal in my narrative. The orange blossom had held at the throat of my jacket and when I hung it on the chair the room leaned toward me as if to ask what I had learned.

Later, when sleep did its patchwork, I dreamed I was inside a library where all the books were ledger paper and each column had my handwriting and every I was here had a smudge where a thumb had gone not quite through but tried. The librarian wore Tasha’s raspberry nails and said I could take out only three at a time, and when I protested she insisted, smiling, that rationing makes you spend slower and love harder. I woke with the scarf under my hand like an obedient pet and the first edge of panic not attending, for once, like a bad neighbor. I lay there and watched the weak morning try to convince itself to be day and I felt the weight of my voice in my mouth and the thought I had not dared think yet was this: there might be a place on the map where everything will either decide or undo, and we are walking toward it not because we love to be ruined but because all the streets we choose are the same street in the end. I did not write that in the lemon book because some lines do not want paper near them yet. I wrote instead, tomorrow buy more flour, and put the pen down like a promise.

The week had a new hinge. It swung easier some hours, stubbornly others, and I learned to listen for the squeak the way you listen for a kettle when you’re in the next room. I wore the orange blossom and watched men with clipboards pause in doorways like they had forgotten what they came for and then remember. I spoke my name to empty rooms sometimes, a superstition that embarrassed me if I thought about it too hard, so I tried not to. Tasha collected her plants from the windowsill on a Wednesday and introduced them to the light with the gravity of a god. “This is Meyer,” she told the sun, and then she turned to me and pressed her forehead to mine without touching and said, “This is where we make the warm ourselves,” and I told her I was not that kind of appliance and she grinned and said, “You are,” and then cried after she’d said goodbye to Mr. Boone in the supply closet because she is the kind of person who gives her best minutes to places that will miss her later and pretend they don’t.

She sent me a picture from her new place a week later of a desk with a toy robot and a plant with long hair and a mug that said “make it weird,” and she wrote, they clap when I say I’m leaving for lunch, and then, I think I might learn to like applause that doesn’t require me to sing. I sent back a photo of the lemon notebook with the page titled People and under it my tidy list of the ways the day had agreed to see me: the dry cleaner who said “sweetheart” in the direction of my shoulder and meant me, the child who looked straight at me and declared my hair a color, the woman at the pharmacy who asked what perfume and then, without waiting, said, “Orange blossom, good choice,” and my own voice, my honest, tacky savior.

Mara kept the scarf in her bag like a talisman, and sometimes, in an elevator or at the bottom of a hospital stairwell when she had fifteen years of air left between tasks, she texted, tie? and I texted back yes even if my hands were busy, because the act itself did a kind of work that breath couldn’t. Annabeth, in the way of a person who is good at not making too big a meal of your fear, sent me an email with a list so simple it could be printed on a recipe card: “smell, sound, color, friction, name,” and I taped it inside a cabinet where the bowls live so I could read it while I found the right one for cereal. My father took to pausing at the threshold of rooms like a man about to say grace and then remembering he did not need to. He would glance at the coin and I would see in his eyes the quick calculation of days he had not been a certain kind of man and he would smile a small private smile and then say, louder, “Tea?” because sometimes you do not say hope out loud because you are afraid it will leave through the window if it hears its own name.

On a Thursday that did not announce itself as important, my mother called. Her number was a geography I do not travel and I watched it ring twice before I picked it up because I wanted to practice not wanting. She began not with hello but with, “I am near a pier that is ashamed of itself,” and in the background I could hear gulls and the sound of a man dragging a cooler as if everyone in California must have the same neighbors as ours. She said she had been thinking of the word undertow and had decided it made people blame the water for wanting what it wants and that she preferred riptide because it sounded like a mood. She told me a woman named Wally had invited her to a reading on a boat and she had said yes even though boats make her remember that she is small, and then she said my name correctly and it was as if a bird had flown into a window and remained whole anyway.
