She asked me if I had been happy lately with a consideration that startled me, the way strangers can be so kind that you feel both loved and anonymous, and I said, after a breath that felt like a rehearsal, that I had been something near it and sometimes inside it and once in a while exactly it. “Good,” she said, as if I had put a check beside a box she had been carrying around all day. “Someone should be,” she added, and then she told me the shape of the fog on the bay and how it made blades out of ordinary things and I wanted to ask her who taught her to miss people sideways, but the call was already ending in that way some calls do, the way that makes you feel like a commercial for a product you both won’t buy.

It was Mara who said it, like a dare and like a gift, in the quiet after my mother’s voice had left my walls. “One more ocean before the cold,” she said. “A meaner one than Jersey. Not because I want to be punished but because I want to stand next to a true thing and feel it not lie to me.” I looked at the map in my head where money sits like small weights and I saw the lines we could draw and where they would arc and what they would ask of the ledger, and I said, “We will find a ticket under the couch,” and she smiled because sometimes her belief in my tricks is the only magic I accept. Flights are the kind of extravagance that if you squint can look like prudence; time is money in a way that money never manages to be time. We bought two seats to Boston with a credit card that looked at us and shrugged and said, “All right,” and we promised ourselves we would sit in the airport like ladies who have always known how to read the departures board with elegance.

I was worried about the machines. Annabeth did not laugh. “They will like you more than the doors,” she said. “They do not have to decide in the same way. You will be light on their screens and heavy where it matters.” At the airport the first automatic door, perhaps out of regional pride, made a show of opening for us three full steps before it needed to, and I pretended to curtsey. At the security line, a man with a badge that had his name but not his face smiled at Mara and then gave his smile to the tray into which she put our shoes. I took off my bracelets and they clinked like a sentence under heavy punctuation. The woman at the scanner had a voice like a good bus driver, loud without cruelty. “Step in. Feet on the yellow. Hands up.” I did what she said because I am sometimes a doer when told. The cylinder purred around me and the picture I could not see made someone I could not see nod and then shake their head. “Again,” the driver said, softer. Mara had already put her shoes on and was rolling her eyes at her own feet, which always forget one sock in the corner of her bag. “Again,” the woman said one more time, the third with the kind of patience good people mistake for duty. When I stepped out she motioned me gently with an open palm to the side where another agent held a pair of hands over a table as if warming them for a song.

“We’re going to do a pat down,” she said, very formal, and her eyes kept sliding to my left in that way people have started to watch the air. “Consent?” she added, and I wanted to hug her for remembering the word that makes it all bearable. “Consent,” I said, and she did her careful pressing, the back of her hand where there are laws about how to touch even when touching is part of the job, and it was not that she passed through me; it was that she seemed to find the edges of me where they were clearest and move around the places the world had left blank like a person stepping around a puddle in the dress she saved up for. “Thank you,” she said, as if I had granted her a favor by existing, and we both pretended I had not been a question.

On the plane a woman with a magazine and nails the color of cherries took the seat across the aisle and fell in love with the baby two rows up without ever introducing herself. Mara squeezed my knee when the sky tried to argue with the wing because planes are good at reminding you that you are in a box floating in a mood. I held the scarf under my palm and tried to remember the exact feeling of her skin when our hands still docked without a broker. The city was a puzzle we left behind for someone else to finish. In the air, the landscape gives up form and turns into narrative; rivers are lines, lakes are commas, clouds are a paragraph the wind is editing. When we dropped into Boston, the ground came up to meet us like an old friend who has been practicing how not to hurt you with enthusiasm. The airport there smelled like salt and coffee and the first day of college. The taxi driver had a picture of a boy in a soccer uniform propped on his dashboard where the fish had sat in ours. He told us, without being asked, the best places to get chowder, and then, without meaning to, the story of the time he got lost on the way to his wife in labor and how the baby had forgiven him eventually by coming home late every day from school for a month like a ritual.

We drove up the coast in a borrowed car with a heater that sounded like an argument. The signs were full of towns that made my mouth feel like it was learning an accent. Marblehead. Gloucester. Rockport. The water here did not fuss; it brooded. The rocks were not decorations; they had jobs. We stopped where a woman in a red hat told us to because everybody tells travelers the same secrets and we believe them because we want to be on the right side of the myth. The wind went straight through my sweater with the candor of an old aunt. The smell was the kind that makes your teeth answer, clean and briny and the opposite of sweet. We found a stretch of path that had been obliged to exist by generations of people who insisted that walking beside trouble is part of a life well-lived. The railing was a moral suggestion, not a promise. Mara took her camera out not to take pictures but to make her hands behave like visitors.

We walked with our bodies angled forward, not because we were eager but because the wind asked us to introduce ourselves. The tide was in a mood. The rocks took it as they had always taken it, with the resigned nobility of elders at weddings. A woman in a mustard coat was laughing into her scarf and a man with a face the color of a good table watched her as if the laugh were a sport he had paid to see. Mara pointed with her chin toward a place where the water tried and tried at a seam in the rock, a rhythm older than our superstition. “This is the one,” she said, and then added, “not for drama but for scale,” and I nodded even though nodding in this wind felt like giving away part of your face.

We sat when the railing insisted we should and when we got up we pretended we had not been obeying. I looked for my shadow because I am a fool and because keeping count of how many times the world remembers me has become like counting your steps when you don’t want to think about death. It came and went in the stubby way northerly light makes everyone a little shorter. Mara put her hand palm-up near mine without quite touching and I lowered mine into that waiting the way you set a feat of pastry into an oven and then do not open the door. We did not make a shape the world could recognize. We made an intention and left it there between us where the sea could borrow it for a minute like a dish left to cool.

There are towns in Massachusetts where the houses are so clean-faced you feel you must ask permission to breathe. Ours had an inn with wallpaper that looked like someone had painted the inside of a shell and thought better of it halfway through. The woman at the desk put down a ledger like a stage prop and I loved her on sight for giving paper the respect I give it. She handed Mara a pen as if passing a baton in a race and then, to me, a key with a heavy fob that said 12 in an ambitious font. The key weighed like proof. I carried it with ceremony and set it on the table in our room like a bell we would ring when the evening needed to change shape. In that room, which had two chairs that had not agreed on who should be comfortable, the window gave us a slice of ocean the way pie is sliced for greedy cousins. We shrugged off our coats grudgingly and I rubbed my hands together in the old childish way that makes parents say you will set yourself on fire and then I cupped them around my mouth and said my name softly and watched my breath fog the glass and declare me present and then decide I had been presumptuous and recede.

Night here was a different animal than the night at home. It hunted slower, with better posture. We went down to the small restaurant where men pretended to know oysters and women actually did and the chalkboard claimed chowder three times as if to prove it would not run out if it were forced to repeat itself. The waitress wore her hair like a vote and called everyone friends and meant it as a bribe. We ate, because eating is how you say yes to a place, and Mara made the soup seem like an event. I watched the color on her mouth and decided that lipstick is a kind of announcement I had been too timid to make my whole life. We walked home with our hands in our pockets like teenagers who have stolen cigarettes and are pretending the cold is the reason their fingers feel wrong.

In bed, under a duvet that clearly came from a catalog that arrives addressing you as if you are already who you want to be, we made our small adjustments. The scarf lay between our pillows like a referee that does not blow its whistle. The heat knocked in the wall like an upstairs neighbor. We talked in that sleepward way that makes sentences sound like recipes mumbled in kitchens you have loved. I said, because the thoughts had lined up and recruited me as their witness, that this place felt like the kind of place where you find out who is brave and who simply looks it. She said, because she is the sort of person who finds courage in the correct drawer, that the difference is irrelevant when the wave is knee-high and very relevant when it is not, and that either way she did not plan to go in past her thighs. I told her that a thigh is a promise as well as a body part and she laughed into the pillow and told me to save metaphors for when the restaurant ran out of pie.

Morning made us new. It always tries. We put on clothes that made us look like we intended to be dignified about wind, which is a farce and also a fight worth picking. We stood on the rocks because everyone stands on the rocks; it is the choreography of visitors, and we would not insult the dance by pretending an originality we did not have. I tied the scarf around my wrist and then around hers and the knot perversely looked like a heart and we rolled our eyes at the coincidence and let it be. A man with a dog said to watch our step and then looked a hair left of my face and repeated it as if he had told the news to the wrong person first and was correcting his etiquette. We thanked him in stereo.

Down the path a woman in a purple hat was making a devotional of photographs. She crouched, she stood, she crouched again, the way belief makes you bob sometimes. The water did its long arithmetic against the granite. It sent up spray in small astonishments. There was a spot where the steps had been carved into the stone by someone with a patience you only see in New England carpenters or thieves, and the salt had done its bleaching and sanding so that sometimes you forgot the steps were not bones. “Not down there,” Mara said, not because she thought I would but because she needed to hear herself say a boundary out loud. The wind played the old joke of trying to pull my hood off my head. I put it back on, not because I wanted to keep my hair dry but because I wanted to quarrel with an element and win one small round.

We stood where the spray could pretend to baptize us without truly wetting our feet. The sea made that sound that is so much like a crowd that you almost turn to see if strangers have decided to sing. I put my mouth near her ear and I said, lightly to prove I can still be light, that the lemon notebook was sitting in the room on the desk and would likely, if it could, write in itself about the angles of this place. She turned and her cheek brushed the scarf and the scent of orange blossom rose like a forgiveness, and she made her surprise face at the way it moved through the cold, and she said she wanted to sit in a pew that smelled like this when she was old. We made a plan without making it: after this rock, that one; after that one, the bench; after the bench, the path back where tea gloats and we let it. Plans are a religion we practice because nothing else asks so little.

The first big shot of water came when we were not looking, because that is how show-offs work. It was theatrical and not mean, and it wet our jeans to the shin and made the child part of me giggle and the adult part of me inventory our phones. The second did not arrive soon after because it was not the second; it was an accountant wave, biding time, waiting to be wise. Between the two, the sun shouldered through a stripe of cloud and made the wet rock shine in a way that makes it look like a coin you want to pick up even if someone tells you it belongs to a saint. The old saying about never turning your back is the sort of thing people write on magnets, and you forget until the day the ocean spouses itself to your story without your consent. We did not turn our backs. We were not heroic. We did the stupid smart thing of thinking we knew the shape of a minute.

A gull cried like a hinge. The dog barked at its shadow. A group of teenagers at the far end of the path made the noise all teenagers make, the one that is laughter and a dare. The light went a little sideways. “After that splash, home,” Mara said—and then stopped talking, because discourse had to be negotiated with the air. I stood, the way you stand when you are inside the picture and you do not want to drain it of anything by moving. The wind took a breath. The sea gathered etiquette or nerve, I cannot say which.

We saw it begin: the curl far out, the suggestion of a shoulder about to be thrown. It’s odd what the eye decides to narrate. I remember thinking, from nowhere sensible, that this was the exact color of a bruise that starts to heal. I remember seeing the scarf’s knot and thinking I should have learned a different one, the kind sailors use that knows how to be loyal. I remember the shape of Mara’s mouth changing not to fear but to work. The water stood up. It is hard to tell this part without making it more polite than it was. It was not a cliff falling on a church. It was not a window shattering into roses. It was water, and the sky took a mouthful of her because that was the piece of the world nearest to it that could prove gravity is only a suggestion when the ocean is in the mood.

There was a sound I cannot put into music. It was wood and teeth and a choir chair being dragged across linoleum. The wave came not in a sheet but in a hand with too many fingers. It reached around the shoulder of the rock and made a small correction in our math. The scarf tightened and then tried to think. The knot did its best work, which was not enough work for this. Her knees went light. My feet found nothing they trusted. The railing where it was a suggestion suggested we hold it; I held air and the memory of wood and the memory was generous but it forgot to be solid. The teenagers were suddenly saints, one of them shouting hoarsely, the kind of hoarse that takes hours of laughing to earn, and the dog took three authoritative steps backward because dog wisdom is the better kind. I said her name with my chest. The wind said no in five dialects. The scarf, faithful as an oath said too fast, slid.

Bodies do what bodies are born to do. She reached with that left hand I have watched tie a thousand patient knots on childhood and grown-up tangles and it went through the place my right hand had earned by long practice and could not make now. The world glitched; it did not stop. I felt the heat of her near me the way you feel an idea right before it arrives. Then the wave took the back of her coat in its mouth and stepped down from the stage. The step wasn’t dramatic. The step was banal, the way accidents in kitchens are banal, a cut that bleeds more than is fair. She went forward and down with grace because she is that kind of woman even in physics. The scarf went slack in my palm in that obscene way cloth goes dead when it is not being asked to be a boundary anymore.

I did not scream, not at first. Not because I am brave. Because there is a lag when something your theory of the world depends on is revised by water. The man with the dog shouted something that had numbers in it; a number you dial when you are correct and want to feel you participated. The mustard coat ran. The teenagers turned into rescue, the verb. There was a rope somewhere because men in towns like this are never more than thirty feet from a coil of rope in any season. Someone threw the rope too short. Someone else threw it like he had been born for this offering. The wave that had taken a bite rolled her further than I wanted a person I loved to roll and then did the decency of letting her show her face, coughing and furious, and then the stone took her side like an indifferent friend, blocking what it could of the fuss. I moved because my body, the part of it that can still vote, told me the worst sin is theater when someone is drowning. I got on my knees because a nun in me remains. I put my hands into the wave with the gall of a child who has never had to ask permission. It gave me cold. That is the truth I will never argue with it about. It gave me cold and noise and the memory of her shoulder between my palms and the precise knowledge that I would trade math for touch for the rest of my days and the universe will not accept that currency.

When they got a loop around her waist she did not fight as hard as you would think. She is practical, and she is not the sort of person who refuses help because pride is a more precious possession than breath. The men leaned their weight back in a mutual trust fall with rock and salt supervising. The rope, honest in the way rope is, did what it had been taught. The water tried, like a suitor with poor timing, and was refused. She came against my knees and I made a cradle of my lap that my lap could not be, and she lay half on the stone and half on an ambition we had both been keeping. Her eyes met mine, not cinematic at all, just two tired eyes trying to find the place to rest that does not require apology. “Okay,” she said, not to me, to the moment, like a woman agreeing to be put under for a surgery she wants to wake from. Then she coughed and rolled and sat and put the heels of her hands into her eyes as if to push the sea back with bone.

Many things happened around us in ritual order: phones gave up their attention to maps and acquired it for the men in coats; a siren placed its color in the air like a marker; the woman with the purple hat kept taking pictures even though decency had a case to make against her, and she kept them for herself, not because she was cruel but because sometimes you witness and your only language is to collect. The wind selected a few sentences and tore them up just to show us it could. The rope fell into obedient loops on the ground like something that would ask to be put away properly later and be thanked for its service. The scarf, traitorous and faithful both, lay against my thigh and I wanted to bite it and kiss it and tie it around the neck of the sea.

Inside the inn, the woman with the ledger turned into a nurse with a kettle and a wool blanket without having to change clothes. She made tea the way instruction manuals tell you to make tea and forced mugs into our hands that I held because heat and ceramic are a church too. Mara was shivering and telling her body to quit the dramatics, the way she tells a machine to stop an alarm with a palm like a blessing, and we did the little obedient things people do after large resistances: we took off wet socks, we rubbed ankles with the corners of towels, we said we were fine, we said thank you enough times that the word turned into its sound without meaning. The purple hat sat two chairs away and did not have the grace to look sorry; she had the grace to look earnest, which is sometimes better.

When we were alone, the kettle quiet after impressing itself on the room, we looked at the lemon notebook on the bedside table. It was open because I had left it that way as if to let the day write its name when we were gone. I picked up the pen and wrote with a hand that had learned nothing and everything, “rock path, rope, wave with a mouth,” and the ink did not pool; it sank right in, thirsty as if I had finally been telling the truth with the right nib. Mara took the pen and wrote, very small and very neat, “did not die,” and then put a period, not because she believed in conclusions but because she needed to end one sentence.

We drove down the coast later than we meant to, not because we were afraid of the place but because we were a little in love with it, the way you sometimes keep talking with a person who has been rude because their rudeness was honest and it taught you something useful about your own manners. In Boston we returned the car like people who had taken a child to the park and not let it run past the fence. At the airport the doors opened in the same mean way every time, as if they had decided to stop mocking me and simply perform their trick. The scanner hummed and the woman with the bus driver voice nodded me through with the efficiency of someone who has had enough miracles for one shift and is not collecting any more. On the plane, a man across the aisle snored with a toddler’s abandon and the flight attendant smiled like a woman who had seen worse and will again.

Back home, the river had retreated into behaving and the dog with the saint’s face was asleep in a patch of afternoon like he had rented the square for the hour. Vivian put her hands on my cheeks and then on Mara’s and then on the air in front of the two of us and laughed because sometimes laughter is cheaper than panic and tiny enough to go in your pocket. My father took one look and sat down because sitting is his act of respect when the story has been larger than is fair. He pressed the coin into my palm with the relief of a man handing back a baby and told me to keep it until the end of the week, and I did not argue because sometimes being obedient is the kind of love that matters.

Night fell and I did not go to sleep. I sat with my ledger like a widow with knitting and I wrote I was here not in the line but in the margin, as if I needed to say it off record, away from the part that will be audited. The ink behaved. My voice behaved, when I used it to make the word sound in the kitchen at two in the morning. The scarf lay on the back of a chair and looked like a snake that had decided to understand compassion. Mara wrote from three floors and two blocks away that she could still feel the sea in the cartilage of her ears and that she planned to fall asleep saying the name of every fish she could think of to put a fence around it. I wrote back that I could come over and read her a taxonomy and she replied with the word “later,” the way people promise to keep living, and I held the phone warm until it cooled, and when I finally set it down it made the smallest noise on the table, a coin, a stone, a proof.
